Sir;

I have the honour to bring the Department's attention to the attached Voucher No.424, amounting to $741.60 in favour of Mr. A.S. Hanna of Port Alberni, B.C., the amount being his account on a 25% basis profit on material and labour costs for plumbing and heating work done at the Christie Indian Residential School during September, October, November and December, 1929.

The certificate attached to the said voucher No.424 is intended to certify that the amount charged is 25% of the cost of material and labour used and supplied on the work in question, as shown in the detail of costs attached to the voucher.

As no percentage allowable to Mr. Hanna for his services has been specified by the Department and as no other work has been done in this Agency on a percentage basis, I am not prepared to certify that Mr. Hanna's charge, the percentage usually allowed and that it is fair and just.

Your obedient servant,

Ed. E. Flett
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Office of the West Coast Indian Agency,
Port Alberni, B.C.

January 15th,1930

The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir;-

The cost of the Plumbing and Heating at Christie School, ran considerably over the estimates. This was due to the fact that after Crane's Heating Engineer had looked over the work he advised adding another section to the boiler to give a bigger body of water, as the boiler is situated at one end of the buildings. For the same reason he advised putting in a Thrush control system to help circulation. Also when the system was filled up the old work was found to be defective in many places and had to be overhauled generally.

Yours truly,

(sd) A.S.Hanna.
West Coast Agency,
Fort Alberni, B.C.

October 16, 1930.

Memorandum:

IR. SCOTT.

With reference to that portion of Bishop Murray's letter, which is concerning the Christie Indian Residential School, I may say that the buildings are not fireproof, nor are they very suitable for the purpose of educating Indian children. The original wing has been added to from time to time. On the other hand, I understand that this school is quite habitable yet and, in addition to improvements that the church may have effected, the Department has expended $17,240.00 during the last four years in enlarging the school, providing fire protection, installing water supply, electric light and heating equipment.

The following schools in British Columbia have as much, if not more, claim for new buildings as Christie:-

St. Mary's, Squamish,
Ahousaht, Cariboo.

Russell T. Ferrier

Supt. of Indian Education.
October 6, 1930.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

It is quite necessary at Christie School that some kind of locker arrangement be made for keeping the clothes of the girls, that the present store room for food supplies be enlarged and generally improved, and that part of the floor of the laundry, recently burned away due to the collapse of the ironing and hot water stove, be replaced. The estimated cost of these repairs and improvements is $300.00. May I respectfully ask the Department to come to my assistance to that extent?

Very truly yours,

Victor Hassier, O.S.B.
Ottawa, October 18, 1930.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 6th instant, with reference to repairs at the Christie Indian Residential School. The Department regrets that the Appropriation for Indian Education is entirely assigned for this fiscal year and that authority cannot be granted at the present time.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

FIRE PROTECTION:

The fire escapes consist of a wooden stairs and a wooden ladder attached to the back wall of the school. Neither of these is used for fire drill purposes. In fact, when I wanted to hold a fire drill I could not, as the children had not been drilled and would not have known what to do. I did my best to impress upon the Principal the necessity of teaching the children how to make their exit from the building in case of fire. I requested him to hold fire drills, at least once a month. I should be glad if the Department would impress on the Principal the absolute necessity of holding regular fire drills.

The exits to the fire escape and ladder are nailed. There is an axe in each dormitory. Two of the staff sleep in a room from which there is no proper exit in case of fire. Should they be cut off on the inside of the building, they could not escape. I am not satisfied with the facilities for escape in case of fire.

I beg to recommend that a system of four fire gongs be installed at the earliest possible moment.
Ottawa, September 29, 1931.

Rev. Sir:

Mr. School Inspector Barry is not at all satisfied with the facilities for escape in the event of fire at the Christie Indian Residential School. The most serious situation was the failure to have fire drill. This practice should be repeated regularly every two weeks, if not often, particularly at the beginning of the academic year and before the fires are used for heating purposes. Unfortunate experiences in the past have impressed upon the Department the absolute necessity of regular fire drill.

To facilitate fire drill and to improve the facilities for sounding an alarm, the Department wishes you to install fire gongs at the earliest possible opportunity. At other schools this equipment has been put in the buildings at a very moderate expense, and I have to request that you will ascertain what is needed and make the installation. A properly certified account, in duplicate, may be forwarded for the materials.

WEST COAST AGENCY INSPECTION REPORT.

CHRISTIE RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

I also landed there and went over this school. The locality of this building also, is about as poor as could be chosen from the point of view of landing freight. The Rev. Principal, who was not there at the time of my visit, possesses a wharf, but from what I can make out, this is entirely unpracticable. Whether or not it would be good or practical to build a road from the school to Opitsat Reserve or not, to get landing facilities, I do not know. This is an old building, and personally, I do not like the fire hazard. I believe a fire alarm system was supplied some time ago, but it has not yet been installed. The fire escapes or ladders are badly placed, being in angles, at the back of the building on the lee side from the prevailing winds. This would cause drafts and much smoke. One of the so-called escapes, placed on a flat wall at the back, is one of the most stupid arrangements I have ever seen called an escape. It is a flat, wooden ladder, nailed against the wall at a most difficult angle from the escape window, with no ladder. It does not reach the ground by about fifteen feet and is broken in the middle. It is impossible, in my opinion, for women, or young children, and most men, particularly with smoke around, not to slip or fall.

The rooms and building were clean and well kept, but the floors are going rapidly. New bakery ovens are required and a proper place for the manual training, at present, in a small shed. Some clearing was being done for a play ground, departmental expense, I understand. I suggested to the Rev. Father in charge temporarily, that the Department would like Indians from the neighbouring village employed on the work to help them over the bad times.

Dear Sir:

While the Department's letter of the 25th ultimo, File No. 159-0-5, refusing my application for a refund, has placed me in a very uncomfortable position because of certain obligations I took upon myself on the strength of Mr. Ferrier's assurance that this assistance would be forthcoming, I realize I have no alternative but to reconcile myself to the inevitable and make the best of a very trying situation.

Furthermore, your reference to estimates being prepared for the next fiscal year has further served to disturb me in that on another promise of Mr. Ferrier I have purchased dormitory supplies to the amount of $800.00, he having advised me that such a sum would be refunded to me at the beginning of the next fiscal year.

That you may understand my plight permit me to explain that in the last four months I have been compelled to make extensive repairs to the buildings, replacements in sidewalks and the like about the place, and improvements which I felt could no longer be delayed. Two of these I think deserving of special mention here:

(1) Our baking problem had assumed most serious proportions in that our bake oven had burned out and that the doctor had found mixing the dough quite strenuous for the girls who, by circumstances, were compelled to perform that task. The purchase of a new oven, dough mixer and engine, the construction of an addition to house these have cost me over $2000.00.

(2) Another item of heavy expense, of approximately $5,000.00, was the clearing, draining and leveling of a piece of land to supply the children with some kind of recreation grounds, as they have almost nothing in that line.

Allow me to stress the fact that in both undertakings all work that could possibly be entrusted to the Indians was performed by them at days wages. We distributed the work as judiciously as we could, engaging Indians from Hesquiat, Ahousaht, Keltsamart and Clayoquot reservations. June 5, 1934.

Dear Sir,

The following repairs and improvements to Christie School were, or are in course of being made, by me because carrying on without them had become virtually impossible. When completed they will represent an expenditure of approximately $4,000.00. The monastery to which I belong, after the Superior had investigated and found conditions deplorable as I had described them, was good enough to make me a loan of $3,000.00 to enable me to proceed.

These facts and the following resume of what has been done and is being done are brought to your attention in the hope that if it is ascertained these repairs were as necessary as I have represented them to be, the Department may consider it but fair to assist me to some extent in removing the financial responsibility I have assumed. I am sure it will be found upon investigation that I only did that which the Department would have found itself eventually compelled to do. Christie School should not be closed. Permit me to assure you that in every instance every effort was made to be as economical as possible both in deciding what was necessary and in purchasing materials.

(1) Slip: All freight, etc., intended for Christie School must be hauled up the slip. This is in bad shape, the Ford engine which up to now turned the winch, will no longer serve, a shed at the bottom of the slip to protect the freight from rain which often over-takes us while unloading, and another shed to house the winch and engine are necessary. A second hand Novo hoist at $350.00 and most of the material for repairs to the slip and construction of the sheds have been purchased.

(2) Freight Dory: the old one had been in service so long and repaired so often that further overhauling was a waste of money and effort; and besides the condition of the dory constituted a menace to life. A new one was constructed at a cost of $170.00.

(3) Boys' Toilets: because a nuisance to health as well as to order replacing them could no longer be postponed. A second-hand range of six toilets has been purchased which we hope soon to place in a new structure a short distance from the main building. Materials for the structure have still to be purchased.

(4) Electric Wiring: the fire hazard from the faulty wiring of the building was appalling and the drain on electric current due to the same reason shortened the life of batteries considerably. After a careful study of the problem it was decided that nothing would be better than remove the old wiring and replace properly. The work was done by one of my maintenance men, a skilled electrician, with the aid of the senior boys.

(5) School Desks: We were not only short in number, but the old desks and make-shifts made to serve as desks were collapsing from age and use. The necessary number were purchased and set up.
(6) Painting: painting the interior and exterior of the building was necessary not so much to improve the appearance of the institution but to save from further deterioration what is left of it. Only a small portion of the structure had been originally painted some 30 years ago. The boys under the supervision of one of the maintenance men have done most the building, besides mixing practically all of the paint used after I had purchased the ingredients.

(7) Floors: The floors in parts of the building, e.g., the kitchen, dining rooms, sewing room, girls' living room and the corridors, were badly worn; in some places entirely worn away. These floors have been replaced in part.

(8) Drains and Water Main: parts of the drainage system about the building had to be replaced due to the fact that water was seeping through the walls of the building and flooding especially those parts of the basement where are located the boys' wash and locker room, boiler room and storage room. Sections of the main water line, due to faulty laying, had deteriorated and were leaking badly, threatening our water supply. New sections have been purchased and the old replaced.

(9) Drier: the drier in the laundry was heated with hot water in consequence of which it was impossible to get the clothes dry. Following wash days practically every radiator in the house had its burden of clothes to dry, and ironing was a long drawn-out process. A 2,99 H.P. steam boiler and necessary piping was purchased and substituted for the old hot water boiler at a cost of approximately $300.00.

(10) Batteries: The old lighting batteries were completely exhausted. A new set has been purchased at a cost of approximately $600.00. The rambling, spread-out construction of the building, necessitating the use of an extremely large number of lights, made it necessary to install batteries capable of sustaining a very heavy load.

Permit me to call your attention, also, to the expenditure of more than $5,000.00 during the school year 1932-1933 to provide the children with a play-ground. This was also made possible through the kind assistance of our monastery. The work constituted clearing land, removing stumps from, draining and filling in, a swamp, and installing an elaborate drainage system. The particular point to which I would call your attention is the fact that, excepting supervision by three white men, all the work was done by Indians, every reservation being represented but the most northern, the "Yugust." To these Indians went the large bulk of the $5,000.00 expended in the form of wages at $1.85 a day; and there can be no doubt that the Department was relieved of no small item of expense in the way of relief by the wages earned in this undertaking.

Two matters I would beg you to consider with approval are the following:

(1) A resident nurse: Christie School and the Catholic tribes of the West Coast Agency stand very much in need of a trained nurse. The need is created by con-
tions that present a problem which seems to admit of no other solution. The tribes live on reservations scattered along the coast. The nearest hospital is at Port Alberni, a twelve hours journey from the nearest reserve by the C. & R. steamer which plies the coast three times a month. It is quite out of the question to expect the doctor residing at Tofino to give the Indians and the school the attention and care that is necessary, whereas a nurse, appointed for the task of visiting the reserves regularly and with headquarters at the school, would be in a position to accomplish much.

The present arrangement whereby a field matron is stationed at the Protestant mission at Ahousaht to look after the needs in that respect of the school and the neighboring reserve, while the Catholic School and nine Catholic tribes are compelled to do without such an asset, is most unfair. While the understanding seems to have been that the matron was appointed with the entire northern section of the agency as her field of activity, the fact of the matter is, she has always confined her ministrations to the one school and the one reserve. It should be added furthermore that the present matron has made herself quite undesirable for work amongst the Catholic tribes because of her proselytizing propensities; an objection that very likely should always continue in the event a single matron were appointed to serve the two residential schools and the reservations.

(2) Materials for a structure: a two story structure of approximately these dimensions: 30 x 40 feet. At present we have but the one room, 20 x 32 feet, which must serve as study, class and assembly room for all the boys. The structure requested would provide us with two class rooms and a little additional dormitory space, besides enabling us to use the present class-room for a dining room. The present dining room is too small for the number of boys in attendance.

Yours respectfully,

Victor Besser

Mr. MacInnes noted the smell from the place and commented on it when he visited Christie School on August 7th, 1934.

Improvement No. 2. Freight shed at bottom of freight slip. Estimated cost £100.00. Size asked for 24'x18'x10'-storage space 160 cubic yards. In my opinion a freight shed capable of storing goods brought up by steamer in bad weather would greatly assist in the prevention of damage to spoilable goods. But I fail to see the necessity of a storage or freight shed of the size mentioned above, as that space (as in instance or illustration) would accommodate 60 wagon loads of 2 cubic yards each and I cannot imagine anything near that quantity of perishable goods being delivered at that school at any one time. One ton of sacked flour will occupy a storage space, 10'x2'x2', approximately 30 cubic feet.

Improvement No. 3.
Improvement No. 3.— Shed for hoist and engine hoist 10'x20'x8'. Estimated cost $340.00. There is a car engine employed at Christie School; this machine is geared to haul a small freight car over hills by wire cable from the beach to the school level. I fail to see the necessity for a shed of the size asked for or for the use of expensive lumber in the construction of a hoist shelter and shed 10'x20'x8'. Estimated cost $430.00. These are combined in the Rev. Principal's application, but I fail to see what the second shed is intended to be used for.

Improvement No. 4.— 3000 b.f. edge grain flooring grades 1 and 2. The floors in several of the halls and rooms are in a very worn condition and badly in need of reflooring. Estimated cost $150.00. Some of this work was being done during the summer holidays. Worthy of consideration.

Improvement No. 5.— New class rooms and dormitory. No details, the estimated cost of all material, as given by Lemon Johnson Co., Ltd., is $2100.00. F. C. H. host at Kakawis. I respectfully beg to suggest that the opinion of Mr. Inspector A. H. Scott be obtained in this matter as he should be better aware of the needs of the school, as called for by school regulations, than the Indian Agent. In my opinion improvement is needed in the boys class rooms and dormitory. The present pupilage of Christie School is 100, and the school is very seldom up to full strength, the population of the district from which its pupils are obtained is not increasing.

Your obedient servant,

Ed. E. Frost

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing herewith, copy of a letter, received in this office from the Reverend Principal of the Christie Indian Residential School.

The letter being self explanatory. However a very great need will be overcome if the proposed wing can be constructed. The school, as you will remember, is crowded, especially in the winter months, as there are many days when pupils cannot be allowed outside, owing to the very heavy rainfall.

The estimate, is very fair, but a small saving could be made if two by four were used for the frame of the second story instead of six by six. Dear Sir:

With regard to the new addition to be erected at the above institution I am submitting for your consideration and the Department's the estimates which I have received. Again I would lay stress on the crowded quarters of the dormitory and the advisability of separating the small boys from the larger ones. During the rainy season which is rather long here on this coast the boys have no recreation hall which makes it rather difficult both for the prefects and the children. I am sure that such an asset will go far in promoting a better spirit among those under our charge.

The cost of the building complete without the wiring amounts to $4,186.50. The wiring is estimated at $200.00 with the same amount necessary for the towing of the necessary materials to the school. The total cost will be $4,386.50.

Since our income at the school is limited to the per capita grant and the carpenter's allowance we could hardly make the necessary payments on an insurance policy. Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 29th ultimo, enclosing letter received from the Principal of the Christie Indian Residential School with reference to the installation of an oil heating system.

When the Principal receives estimates covering the cost of installing this system they may be submitted for the Department's consideration. EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF MR. G. H. BARRY, INSPECTOR OF INDIAN SCHOOLS, DATED MARCH 25, 1936, ON HIS INSPECTION OF THE CHRISTIE INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

Original on No. 159-0-6.

FIRE PROTECTION: In opening this section of my report, I would ask that a copy of the Department's instructions with regard to fire drills be sent to the Principal. He does not appear to have a copy of this most important letter.

There are seven large Fire Extinguishers and some half dozen Pyrene extinguishers. I could not see any evidence that the Soda type extinguishers had been recharged lately. This I think ought to be done. There are six hydrants with hose pipe located inside the main buildings, and there are three more outside the buildings. There is a quantity of hose pipe for use with the hydrants. The water comes from the mountains through a tank on the side of the hill near the school. The pressure in the fire mains is between 60 and 70 pounds, and will throw water to the roof, I am informed.

I held the usual fire drill while at the school. The Indian Agent and teacher who were with me in the senior girls' classroom did not hear the fire gongs. I was just able to do so, but only because I was waiting for them to ring. There are five gongs and I can only think that they did not all ring through lack of battery power. New dry cells are probably required. The fire drill was well carried out DOWN THE STAIRS INSIDE THE SCHOOL. The only escapes are as described in my last report, a wooden stairs at the back of the school leading to the roof of a low part of the school, and a wooden ladder fixed to the back wall of the school.

I certainly consider that suitable fire escapes should be constructed at the ends of the school building. These need not be of iron. In case of a serious fire at this school I do not see how the children could all be saved. I asked that this matter should receive consideration by the Department, when I previously reported on this school after an inspection in April, 1934. I am simply not satisfied with the protection afforded to the children at this school in the case of fire, and wish to go on record to this effect. I have no doubt that the Indian Agent will be in full agreement with my view of the matter, and I can only think that the officials of the Schools Branch of the Department of Indian Affairs must have overlooked my previous remarks on the fire escape situation at this school.

Report on condition of Fire Escapes and Fire Fighting Appliances at Christie Residential School.

October 20, 1936.

Fire Escapes and Exits.
This school is poorly equipped with fire escapes. The present means of escape is by stairways placed at either end of the building. These however have the advantage of being so placed that the school can be emptied in less than two minutes, and are located in that part of the building least exposed to danger from fire. A new escape is at present under construction which leads from both dormitories, at the girls end of the school.

Pyrenes.
Pyrenes are placed at vantage points throughout the building, and are all in good order. Refills are also being supplied for these.

Fire Pails.
Fire pails are kept on landings, and at time of inspection were filled with water and in good order.

Fire Alarm.
A large gong operated by electric switch is placed on upper landing. This has recently been put in good order. This gong is not considered adequate for the purpose, as it is indistinct at further end of building.

Hydrants.
There are six hydrants with hose located in the main building, and three hydrants outside.

Water.
Water pressure and supply is very good. Pressure about 70 lb. and sufficient to throw a stream over the roof.

Fire Drill.
Fire drills are well conducted. School can be emptied in two minutes by means of exits, under normal conditions. Staff and children know their stations.

Recommendations.
It is recommended that a fire escape of the same type as the one being built (wood construction) be placed at the opposite end of building. In case of fire at boys end of building, escape would be cut off, should the stairway be involved. It is also recommended that a larger gong or bell be installed. Estimated cost of wooden fire escape and gong, labor to be provided by school staff, $100.00. It is further recommended that present roof of wood shed be torn down, as this is of cedar shake construction and very dangerous being directly opposite kitchen flues. This is being dealt with in separate letter.

Respectfully submitted,

Indian Agent.

PBA/AM.

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

The sum of $900.00 is available in the Appropriation for Indian Education for the current fiscal year to carry out repairs, painting, etc., at the Christie Indian Residential School, Kakawis, B.C., west coast of Vancouver Island (Electoral District of Comox-Alberni).

The Principal and the local Indian Agent have made a survey of the present heating system in the building, which, they state, is absolutely necessary to be renewed. In view of the difficulty of obtaining wood and coal, they have recommended the installing of an oil heating system. The obtaining and handling of oil supplies is easily overcome, as the Imperial Oil Company, Limited, Vancouver, propose to keep a supply on hand at Tofino, where it can be obtained and shipped on the school launch. The great difficulty at this school is the handling of freight supplies, and the semi-annual supply of oil can be shipped direct on tanker and taken ashore on a scow, which is the property of the school.

The Imperial Oil Company, Limited,
- Vancouver
Vancouver, furnished a quotation for the changing of the present heating system and boiler, supplying the necessary burners, tanks for oil storage, etc., for the price of $1,300.00, and guarantee satisfactory service for a period of one year from the date of installation.

I would recommend, for your approval, that authority be granted to incur an expenditure of $900.00 for the purpose mentioned, and, as the Principal is paying part of the cost, that the contract to supply the oil burning equipment be given to the Imperial Oil, Limited, Vancouver, from whom the Principal will purchase the oil he requires, from school funds.

Dear Sir,

In complying with your request that our engineers make a survey of the above school, we take great pleasure in submitting to you for your approval our report as follows:

Before we could arrive at a decision as to the feasibility of satisfactorily heating the above school with oil burning equipment, we first made a complete plan of the school and its present radiation, which we give you as follows:

Boiler. The boiler is of a type that will give good efficiency with oil fuel, having a gross radiation of 6050 square ft. output. The condition of the boiler to all appearances is good except the grates and the smoke pipe, which will necessarily have to be renewed.

Radiation and Piping. The complete radiation at present in the school is 4389 square ft. gross. There is a shortage of radiation in some of the rooms, but we feel that with proper firing of the boiler and insulating some of the present exposures, this will be overcome. Some of the piping should be covered, otherwise the heating pipes, locations and capacities are very good.

Burners. The burners we will install would be our Model BS capable of satisfactorily heating your boiler. We would also install an Automatic Burner Model JB in the heating boiler for domestic hot water.

Tanks. We will install 2500 gallons of oil storage and pipe same to burner.

Price. We will install all the above equipment, including the brickwork and bricks, the electric work and all the electrical equipment necessary to make this installation a success, the heating boiler to be controlled by a clock thermostat, for the following price of $1300.00.

Guarantee. We guarantee the above equipment to be installed
in a workmanlike manner, and in accordance with the Provincial Fire and Electrical Regulations for installations governing the same.

And furthermore guarantee this equipment against defective material and workmanship for a period of one year from the date of installation.

We wish to thank you for the opportunity of submitting the above price and proposed equipment, and trust that it will meet with your favour and you will decide to install the equipment in the above school.

Yours very truly,

Imperial Oil, Ltd.

Reverend Sir:

On the occasion of my last inspection of Christie School on December 13th, I, acting upon instructions of the late Rev. Lee, examined the watchman as to his suitability, and regret to inform you that I found him everything but satisfactory.

He not only did not know how to use the fire appliances, but did not know where they were or what they consisted of. He did not know what the fire alarm was, and when shown, did not know how to use it until demonstrated by Father Lee. To the date of inspection he had not visited the hose hydrants or extinguishers. His answers as to his duties and patrol of the building were most alarming, and showed positively that he either had not been made aware of his duties, or that he was completely incapable of carrying them out.

In view of the great danger of fire at your school, it being a wooden building, and the almost certain loss of life should it unfortunately happen, I must request that you take immediate steps to remedy this condition, and report by return what steps have been taken.

As you were away at the time of inspection, I brought the matter to the attention of Father Lee, and asked him to see that this man was made thoroughly acquainted with the location, nature, and use of all equipment. To test hose and hydrants frequently, also extinguishers.

To make him familiar with alarm stations. To make regular patrol throughout the building, basement and outhouses, all through the night, and to report anything out of order to the Principal immediately.

Kindly say if this has been done and also if you are satisfied that this man is fit to assume the responsibility of the safety of your pupils and the school.

Yours very truly,

P.B. Ashbridge,
Indian Agent.

Extract from Inspector Barry's report of March 21, 1938:

May I mention that the windows from the Girls' Dormitories to the fire escape are fastened with a padlock contrary to the instructions of the Department. I spoke of the electric gong system attached to these windows to prevent them being opened, and pointed out to the Principal that the locking of the windows was against Departmental regulations. I asked him to take the matter up with the Department.

In my last report I mentioned that an oil burning heating system had been placed in the school. May I say that I am not satisfied as to the operation of the burners. There is far too much soot formed showing imperfect combustion. Combustion occurs in the brick chimney overheating this. On opening the furnace doors there is at times a mild explosion. All this points to the immediate need for an overhaul by the Imperial Oil people who placed the system in the school, and I would recommend that the Department insist that this be done under the terms of guarantee given to the school by the Imperial Oil Co. The school is now writing to the Firm in question about this matter.

I wish again to point out the need of a very thorough inspection of all boilers at the school, particularly the High Pressure Boiler in the laundry. I would recommend that Mr. Arnall be asked to make a very thorough inspection of boilers and machinery when this is at all possible. It will be remembered that I asked that the Ahousaht Residential School boiler and machinery should be inspected by Mr. Arnall. He might carry out inspection work here at little extra cost to the Department while on the way back from Ahousaht.

Gerald Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

The enclosed account covers the cost of a boiler purchased for use at the Christie residential school.

The boiler inspector reported that one of the boilers at the Christie school was in such bad condition that repairs would not be justified. He accordingly recommended immediate purchase of another boiler to replace it. As this had to be secured at once the Principal was requested to secure it. The attached account covers its cost and I should appreciate it if you would issue purchase order so that it may be paid.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sirs:

In reporting on his inspection of the boilers at the Christie Indian Residential School, Mr. T. J. Arnall states as follows:

"Re Boiler No. 50540 B.C. - This boiler has been very badly neglected. On removing smoke hood it was found to be corroded nearly away. Water had been allowed to lodge on the top sheet which had corroded the beading off all the tubes. Every tube was leaking so test had to be stopped. Some of the tubes were blocked with scot and corrosion. It was difficult to drive a piece of pipe through them. This boiler must be retubed before using it. Cost approximately $65.00."

"Re Boiler No. 15-6 (Ideal) - Boiler in good condition but carrying too high pressure for cast iron. Must be cut down to 30 lbs.

Firebars and carrier frame burnt out. Have been using pieces of pipe laid across the old bars. New set of bars and frame required. Cost $75.00."

The above matters should be brought to the attention of the Principal.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 29th ultimo with reference to a request received for the purchase of gymnasium equipment for the Christie residential school.

For your information I may say that in the current year's appropriation we provided an amount of $500.00 for repairs and improvements at the Christie school, also an amount of $600.00 for purchase of material for a track from the boat landing to the wharf. This latter item was specially requested last fall by the Principal.

Before giving any consideration to purchase of gymnasium equipment I should appreciate it if you would communicate with the Indian Agent and have him consult the Principal at once with a view to determining in what manner the school management would like to expend the $1100.00 provided in the current year's appropriation.

As previously explained to you, in the case of Church-owned schools it is impossible for the Department to exceed the amount specifically provided due to the fact that we have already secured an Order-in-Council authorizing the expenditure of the exact amount in the estimates; namely, $1100.00.

Dear Major MacKay:

With reference to the attached letter 4161/39/D dated June 29th 1939 from Mr. Indian Agent Ashbridge, I may say that owing to the location of the Christie Indian Residential School it is not possible to provide for the children very much in the way of the usual outdoor games.

The actual space around the school is limited, though there is a sandy beach, which might be made more use of I believe; and the weather is mild and very wet. Under the circumstances the more or less constant use of the gymnasium gives the children that physical training which I am trying to encourage in our educational work.

The need for new schools in various parts of the Province is so urgent that I hesitate to recommend the expenditure of money on less essential projects.

As the school is willing to meet over half the cost of the gymnasium equipment it may be that the Department could find the $100.00 asked for, and if any funds exist for such a purpose I would recommend that the Reverend Principal's request be granted. I do not however consider the matter a very urgent one at the present time.

Yours very truly,

AGENT'S REPORT FOR MONTH OF JUNE

Christie Residential school has just re-opened, having taken the summer holidays earlier than the others.

Pupils had just returned and were all apparently in good health, well clothed and cheerful.

The meals served were very good, well prepared and varied.

The new work-shop is about completed and should prove to be of great value in the training of those taking instruction in engineering, carpentry etc.

Dormitories and all parts of the residence were spotlessly clean, and very well ordered.

Fire appliances, escapes etc. all in good order.

Some leakage was found in the drainage system, and the repair work is being done by the staff.

All outbuildings and grounds are well kept and tidy.

As at Ahousaht, a few cases of Tuberculosis were detected and discharged. Several cases of tonsillitis should be treated and a dental survey at a later date.

P. B. Ashbridge,
Indian Agent.

West Coast Agency,
Port Alberni, B.C., Feb. 28, 1939.

Report for February 1939.

Christie Residential school was found in excellent condition. All the outbuildings are well kept, clean and sanitary, as also are boiler room, basement and laundry.

The boilers have been put in first class order to comply with the requirements of the Inspector. All the material for the new vocational training building has been received, and the buildings should be completed within six weeks. Fire equipment, escapes and water hydrants are all in good order, and fire drills regularly carried out.

Dormitories, classrooms and kitchen were all in excellent order. Children are all in good health, clean, well clothed and fed and meals are varied, well cooked and ample.

At this inspection, I was fortunate in meeting His Excellency the Right Reverend the Lord Bishop of Victoria, who was also paying a visit to the school, and with whom I discussed several matters for the betterment of the school generally.

P.B. Ashbridge,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing herewith application received from Mr. Indian Agent Ashbridge, West Coast Agency, for certain improvements and material for the Christie Indian Residential School, in his Agency. I am also enclosing tenders from local firms for the supplies necessary.

It will be noted that the Agent does not recommend the extension of the girls' dormitory and, in this I agree, but I would recommend that the remainder of the requests, amounting to $236.99 for lumber and $120.00 for hardware be approved. There is also hardware to an amount of $205.06 for the Manual Training department, which I think should be a charge against the B.C. Special Vote. This latter amount I would recommend be allowed from that Vote.

With reference to the tender for material, I have eliminated the freight, which was variously estimated by the different firms, as in any case this freight is at a set rate charged by the C.P.R., the only available transportation company. As the Agent considers the quality of the material supplied by the Sproat Lake Sawmills to be of better grade and, as their price is cheaper for some of the material, I would recommend that the total order for the lumber be given to them.

Yours faithfully,

D.M. MacKay.
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

The Secretary,

Dept. of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, ONT.
Dear Sir:

With reference to my letter of January 10th, 1940, enclosing application and tenders for certain improvements to Christie Indian Residential School, as the freight rate as charged by the C.P.R. (the only transportation company available) is the same for all companies, I have amended the tenders on a basis of f.o.b. wharf, Alberni, freight extra.

The Bieddel, Stewart & Welch Co. do not stock a very satisfactory grade of boat lumber, and the Alberni Pacific Lumber Co. can not supply all the requirements. Therefore I would recommend that the order for this material be given to the Sproat Lake Sawmills, who can supply all material in a very good grade. The lumber for the boat slip is the same price from the Sproat Lake Sawmills and the Alberni Pacific Lbr. Co. The remainder of the lumber is cheaper from the Sproat Lake Sawmills, and I would, therefore, recommend that the entire order be given to the Sproat Lake Sawmills Ltd., Kleeceet, B.C.

Yours faithfully,

P.B. Ashbridge.

Sir:

I have the honour to forward for the consideration of the Department a request of the Reverend Principal of Christie Indian Residential School for material necessary for various projects.

In referring to your letter, file 15/15/967, dated August 10th, 1939, it was pointed out that there was a total of $1200.00 appropriated for this school and an application had been made for track material which would have absorbed this amount. The Reverend Principal now states that the proposed track cannot be completed at this time, and requests material to carry out:

1. Extension of Girls' Dormitory.
2. Theatrical stage for Gymnasium.
3. Construction of boat slip.
4. Repairs to old boat.
5. Materials for Manual Training.

To do all this would cost in the neighborhood of $1200.00 and there is only a balance of $776.94 available, and I would therefore respectfully recommend that items 2, 3, 4 and 5 be granted.

I cannot see any necessity for extending the girls' dormitory, as there is quite sufficient accommodation for all the pupils of this school; also it is not a Department owned building and will soon be in need of extensive repairs.

The boat referred to is one purchased from Reverend Anthony Terhaar, and is actually not worth five dollars, but the Reverend Principal states that he wishes to give the boys practical training in boat building.

Attached are tenders from all available sources locally, and in the event of the request being granted, I would recommend those of Sproat Lake Sawmills for lumber (except the quotation for girls' dormitory) and the tender of Gordon & Belyea for hardware. This would total approximately:

February 12, 1940.

Dear Sir:

I desire to refer to your letter of the 25th ultimo enclosing requisitions for material for the Christie Indian Residential School. Very careful consideration was given to these requisitions and the amount of funds available was also considered and it was decided that we could only allow lumber to the value of $336.99 and hardware to the value of $157.07. I enclose for your information copies of requisitions to which we refer in the above regard. Authority has been received from the Purchasing Agent for you to purchase the items mentioned on these two requisitions from firms on the approved list. You may make immediate arrangements to do so and forward the accounts for payment. When these accounts are received the necessary purchase orders will be secured here.

Regarding the supplies required for the manual training shop at the Christie School the cost of these will be paid from the B.C. Special appropriation. As the end of the fiscal year is approaching our funds are becoming rather limited but it has been decided to allow purchase of supplies for the manual training shop to a value not exceeding $150.00. I attach encumbrance requisition No. 2185 and you may purchase the articles you may consider necessary at a cost not exceeding $150.00. In this connection I attach copy of the requisition received. The last five items do not come within the category of supplies for the manual training shop as they are apparently required for the windows in the building. Consequently they were included in the requisition for hardware for repairs to buildings.

Yours truly,

Major D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B. C.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 9th instant, enclosing communication received from Indian Agent Ashbridge, regarding certain supplies required at the Christie Indian Residential School. You may arrange for the purchase of the following:

- 90 feet of 4-inch galvanized iron pipe in 10 ft. lengths, with couplings,

Sir:

Attached please find list of materials required, also tenders on same. The cost of labour in connection with this installation will be borne by the school, but it may be necessary to use some dynamite, in which case the Principal requests that the Department pay for same.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 30th ultimo, I understand from the Purchasing Agent that he can secure practically any type of coupling that is required. Might I suggest that you purchase the hydrants and let me have the following information:

1. Do you require shank couplings that may be attached with clips and tightened with screws, or expanding ring couplings?

2. Advise the number of threads per inch on both the 2 inch and 2½ inch couplings.

3. If a 2 inch and a 2½ inch coupling can be supplied from the hose previously used as a sample, it will assure the purchase of proper couplings.

I understand that both the 2½ inch hose and the 2 inch hose are required in 50 foot lengths, for use at the Christie Indian Residential School.

Sir:
I have the honour to submit the regular Agency Letter, covering conditions within this Agency during the month ending January 31st, 1941.

Schools:

Christie Residential School was thoroughly inspected and found to be in first class order.

Fire drill was carried out very satisfactorily. All fire fighting appliances were in good order.

The pupils were all in splendid health and were clean, well clothed, well fed, attentive and industrious. Splendid progress is being made in vocation training.

Girls were being taught wool combing, carding, spinning and knitting, and are producing first class sweaters socks, etc., through every process from sheep shearing to the finished article. In addition they are being taught needlework, cooking etc.

The boys are being instructed in boat building and repairs, marine engine operation and repair, carpentry etc. Splendid progress is also shown in physical training, and both boys and girls gave a creditable display of gymnastics.

Outhouses, boiler room and laundry were all in first class order. General condition of the school was very good.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

P.H. Ashbridge,
Indian Agent.

There was no provision made in the school Estimates for the supply of these batteries and I am unable, of course, to say whether funds can be provided but, if so, I would recommend that consideration be given to the quotation of the Coyle Batteries Limited for a set of type V.A.11 235 ampere hour batteries at a cost of $497.70 F.O.B. Vancouver. This type has been found to be most satisfactory for the purpose for which they are required.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 18th instant, with reference to the necessity of supplying new batteries at the Christie Indian Residential School.

In the current year's appropriation an amount of $1,000 was included for repairs and improvements and the purchase of new equipment at this school. It is evident from your letter that batteries are required, and you may arrange for their purchase at the cost mentioned, namely $497.70. When forwarding the accounts, you should attach copy of your purchase order.

It would be appreciated also if you would communicate with the agent and the principal with a view to determining the best manner of expending the balance provided in the current year's appropriation. When requesting that funds be included for this school in the current year's appropriation, mention was made of the necessity for repairing the roof and the boat-house at the school.

As a matter of information, would you let me know when the last batteries were supplied for the Christie School.

AIR MAIL

Ottawa, September 3, 1941.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 27th ultimo, with reference to additional repairs, etc., required at the Christie Indian Residential School.

In regard to this school I would refer you to my letter of July 23, last, which was written in reply to yours of July 18. That letter authorized purchase of the batteries.

As you will note from my letter of July 23, there is a balance of $502.30 in the current year's appropriation for repairs and improvements and the purchase of new equipment at this school, provided the cost of the batteries did not exceed $497.70.

The total amount of $1,000 cannot be exceeded, and under these circumstances it will not be possible for the Department to pay the freight charges. These will have to be borne by the school management.

A separate account should be forwarded for the item $18.60 covering the cost of materials for the manual training shop. This voucher should be marked "Pay from B. C. Special".

With the above in mind, you can arrange for the materials required for painting, repairs to roof, repairs to main building, repairs to laundry foundation and floor and also new outside walks.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Sir:

We take pleasure in presenting, for your consideration, our quotation covering a Walk-in Refrigerator and equipment for the Christie Indian Residential School, Kakawis, B. C. It is understood that we would supply a refrigerator 5' x 5' x 6' high inside measurements, insulated with 6" of Palco wool complete with standard Walk-in door, meat hanger, shelving, and guarantee a temperature of 36° F.

Equipment Necessary:

1 - 33/8 1/3 H. P. Universal Condensing unit complete with Briggs's Stratton gas engine.
1 - cross-fin all copper cooling coil.
1 - thermostatic automatic expansion valve.
1 - Silica Cell drier.
25' of 1" exhaust piping.
2 - 90° sweep ells.
All necessary copper tubing, fittings, and freon refrigerant, completely assembled and guaranteed against any defective part for a period of one year from date of delivery, for the sum of $775.00, f.o.b. Vancouver.

It is our intention to set up this job complete in Vancouver and run a test on same for several days before it is disassembled and crated for shipment. The coil and the condensing unit would both be installed on one wall of the refrigerator so that it would be quite a simple matter to have the box lagged together when it arrived at Kakawis without having to send a service man to make the installation.

FULLY EQUIPPED REFRIGERATION SERVICE DEPT. — AUTHORIZED DELCO ELECTRIC MOTOR SERVICE
The machine would naturally be manually controlled and the operator of same would have to, from experience, judge the amount of gasoline necessary to put in the tank so that when the engine ran out of gasoline the temperature in the refrigerator would be approximately 34 to 36° F. This would also apply to the length of time between cycles, that is when it would be necessary for him to start the machine again. As previously stated, we have figured on insulating the walls of the refrigerator with 6" of Palco wool, the reason for this being that the more insulation we have, the less often they will have to start the machine.

We sincerely trust that the above meets with your approval, and should we be favoured with your valued contract, you have our assurance that we will endeavour to merit your confidence by giving you an installation of unquestionable satisfaction.

Yours very truly,

MACKINNON SALES & SERVICE LTD.

REPORT ON WEST COAST AGENCY FOR MONTH OF JULY.

Christie Residential school was thoroughly inspected and found to be in first class order throughout.

Classrooms and most of the interior of the main building have been painted and redecorated during the holiday and the whole has a clean and pleasing appearance.

Due to inability to obtain oil for heating purposes, firegrates are being replaced in furnaces and wood or coal will be used.

Some repairs are needed to plank walks, and this is being arranged for.

The health of the school is excellent and all pupils appear to be happy, well fed and clothed. Meals are well balanced, ample and well cooked.

Attention is being paid to Air Raid and Fire precautions and no undue alarm is being felt or noted following the recent attack on the Coast, north of the school.

Dear Sir:

I enclose herewith Mr. Indian Agent Ashbridge's letter of the 29th ultimo advising that the Principal of the Christie Indian Residential School wishes to install a refrigeration unit in the school and purchase lumber. This letter enclosed a quotation dated February 23, 1942, of Messrs., McLennan, McFeely and Prior Limited for the unit at the price of $521.00 f.o.b. Vancouver. Enquiry was made of this firm as to whether their quotation still stood, and they informed me on the 13th instant that it was now impossible for them to undertake the fabricating of Refrigeration equipment for the reason that they have too many government war projects of AIA priorities which will keep them busy for about one year.

Meanwhile I had written to MacKinnon Sales and Service Ltd. for a competitive bid on this unit and enclose same herewith from which it will be observed that they are prepared to supply the complete unit ready for assembly at a cost of $775.00 f.o.b. Vancouver.

This matter was referred back to Mr. Indian Agent Ashbridge and I enclose his letter of the 26th instant together with that of the Reverend Principal of the 25th instant from which it will be observed that it is desired to purchase the unit in question and also some lumber amounting to $266.52. As the amount granted by the Department for this school amounts to $950.00, the Reverend Principal is prepared to pay the difference between the amount allotted and the cost of the articles; namely, $91.52.

I would recommend approval of the application to the amount of the funds available for this purpose.

Yours faithfully,

August 30th, 1945.

Dear Mr Ashbridge:

You may remember speaking to me once or twice about the advisability of having one of the men staff members sleeping over the boat shop, as a safeguard against fire etc. At the time I did not think it necessary, but lately the more I have thought about it, the more I feel it would be well if we had accommodation for such a man. There is a good brick chimney on the building, and the room is roughed out in one end of the attic. I could get the lumber etc., and we could do the work ourselves, making it a Manual Training project. I do not feel, however, that I can stand the expense of getting a toilet and soil pipe etc.

I would put an outside stair up to a door which we would cut where a window now is. This would give two exits for any man sleeping up there and it would make the room separate from the interior of the building except when the occupant wished to have it otherwise. This would be well as the upstairs is used for a store room and the boys have to go up occasionally.

We would also put in a septic tank, as part of the above project for the older boys. If the apartment would be good enough to give us the toilet complete along with soil pipe etc., we could manage it nicely, and it would be an added safeguard and that seems to me more and more desirable. We have nails and paint etc., and can finish the room inside. The toilet would cost about $25.00, and the fittings and soil pipe about another twenty dollars. We could do it, I think, for under fifty dollars for these two items.

I trust that you may feel yourself able to recommend this project, and that an amount of not more than fifty dollars be granted by the Department. If the Department cared to buy the toilet, it would then come within a priority rating.

Thanking you for your interest in the school generally, and for your suggestion of some time ago, which I hope you can again bring to the notice of the Department, I am,

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Ottawa,
December 7, 1943.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

We recently wrote to Indian Agent Ashbridge informing him that there was approximately $250.00 unexpended of the amount specifically provided in the current year's appropriation for repairs and improvements at the Coqualeetza Residential School. In reply he has forwarded a request from the Principal for purchase of lumber amounting to $395.00 in order to build a boat. The Principal states in his letter that he is prepared to pay any amount over and above the sum available in our appropriation. I enclose the correspondence which has been sent to this office and will appreciate it if you will issue purchase order for the lumber. When submitting your account you should submit the account for the whole amount and we will pay as much as we have on hand. The balance will have to be paid by the Principal and, of course, he should be informed to that effect.

R.A. Hosy,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

I have the honour to refer to your letter of October 13th, 1943, in connection with available balance of current year's appropriation for Christie Indian Residential School.

The Reverend Principal requests that he be supplied with boat lumber as per his list attached. The total cost of this would be $323.00 and only one quotation is obtainable. Rev. J. P. Mulvihill, however, states that should this exceed the amount available, the Church will pay the balance, if agreeable to the Department. Kindly instruct me.

P. B. Ashbridge,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
October 13, 1943.

Mr. P.B. Ashbridge, Indian Agent, Port Alberni, B.C.

According to our records we have either expended or approved an expenditure of approximately $550.00 at the Christie Residential School during the current fiscal year. The total amount provided in the current year's appropriation for repairs and improvements at this school is $800.00. If there are any more repairs that are absolutely essential that you consider can be obtained for the balance of the amount available, this letter authorizes you to proceed with the necessary work immediately, in order to have it completed before the close of the fiscal year.

H.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

With reference to Mr. Phalen's letter of February 8th and West Coast Voucher No. 440, in favour of Gordon and Belyea, Limited, for materials supplied to the Christie Residential School for repairs to the building and for boat construction, I have taken up with the Company the apparent discrepancies in their account, and obtained the following information:

The item 13' 3/4" Wartime Victory Rope 49 lbs @ .21 $10.29 as shown on their invoice should have read:

213' 3/4" Wartime Victory Rope 49 lbs @ .21¢ $10.29

The Company have, however, reduced the weight of rope charged for to 35 lbs., as they have no record of the exact weight of the rope supplied, making a total of $7.35 for the 213 feet.

With reference to the item 150 ft. 3/8" Galv. Fireweld Anchor Chain, the Company's quotation is somewhat confusing in that they quoted the rate as 100 lbs. at $19.50 per 100 lbs. The weight of 150 ft of such chain is 256 lbs, which at $19.50 per 100 lbs. would total $49.92.

The 5650 x 20" Steering Wheel listed on the Purchase Order was supplied and the cost, $11.08, was included in the total of the Company's invoice, but the item itself was not listed.

Gordon and Belyea, Limited, have supplied corrected invoices and these, together with the voucher No. 440, duly corrected to read $611.03, and the original invoice, are forwarded herewith.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C.,

I have your letter of the 7th instant

Philip Phelan,

D.M. MacKay,

Sept. 5, 1945

D. M. McKay, Esq., Indian Commissioner, Box 70
Vancouver, B. C.

Please note attached letter from Rev. J. P. Mulvihill, Principal of the Christi Residential School, requesting a new boiler for their laundry.

P. B. Ashbridge

Ottawa, April 22nd, 1947.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

We have your letter of the 19th instant with reference to a request of the Principal of the Christie Residential School for a new engine for the generating plant.

As you are no doubt aware, the management of the Christie School for many years past, has urged that some arrangements be made to make easier the unloading of supplies that the school requires.

Some years ago we considered the possibility of building a wharf but the estimated cost of this was very high and at one time a Public Works engineer expressed the opinion that any wharf constructed would probably be damaged severely by the first severe storm.

We received representations to build a road from the school to the Indian village where wharfage could be secured and boats tied safely. For this purpose we provided an amount of $10,000 in the appropriation for the fiscal year 1947-48.

Please take up the matter with the Principal and decide what can be done regarding the proposed
road.

In the meantime, we approve the purchase of the new engine at a cost of $400, but this authority will reduce the amount provided for the road to $9,600. As you know, Christie is a church-owned school and consequently we are only allowed to expend the amount specifically provided.

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.

PP/MGD
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Your File 159-0-5 (WT 1)

With reference to Mr. Neary's letter of February 22nd and in particular the final paragraph regarding purchase of a new engine for the generating plant at the Christie Residential School, I am advised by Father Mulvihill that since last summer the plant has been operated by a boat engine borrowed from one of the missionaries but that he will not be able to secure the use of this engine much longer.

Father Mulvihill states that he has contacted Fairbanks Morse Company who can supply an engine suitable for the needs of the school for $400. It would be appreciated if you would advise if funds are available and if it will be in order to purchase the engine referred to.

D. M MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Principal: Rev. P.J. Sheahan

Vocational Training:

Manual Training:
This school appears to be well equipped for courses in both woodwork, metalwork and mechanical training. The Industrial Arts shop contains a circular saw, band saw, wood lathe and small jointer for woodwork, and a large metal work lathe, forge and post drill for metal work. Unfortunately none of these courses were in operation at the time of my visit as the manual training instructor had not reported to the school for duty. I was shown however, two boats made by the pupils, the larger of which had been completed last term. Pictures of these are attached to this report. It is to be deplored that the school is unable to begin its vocational training for these boys at the commencement of the school term.

Domestic Science:
The girls participate in the usual activities of sewing, darning, mending and dress-making, and the girls observed doing this work seemed to be quite proficient. It is felt that the work along these lines could be broadened to include home nursing and home making in general, as some of the other residential schools are doing or are planning to do. The older girls assist with the preparation of the school meals.

Extra-Curricular Activities:
The chief games at this school are basketball, softball and soccer. Because of the isolation of this school the competitions are almost entirely intra-mural. Other activities consist of parties which are held about once a month, concerts which are held less frequently and moving pictures which are shown two or three times a month. The films are chiefly shown for entertainment although an occasional educational picture is shown. In the late spring and the early fall the pupils swim at the beach.

Fire Protection:
3 Hydrants equipped with 200 ft. of hose in good or fair condition.
5 Standpipes, each with 50 ft. of hose, in good condition.
10 Large fire extinguishers which are recharged annually.
5 Pyrene extinguishers.
10 Fire buckets, five in each of the dormitories.
Fire Protection (continued):

An attempt to ring the fire bells disclosed that the batteries which operate this system had run down, and the Principal is having them replaced.

The Principal states that he has been unable to secure an automatic sprinkler system recommended by the Fire Marshal on the occasion of his last visit. This will be installed in the boiler room as soon as it can be obtained.

Dormitories:

The boys' dormitory is overcrowded and the Principal has already suggested that a new building for a staff residence be erected, and that the quarters now occupied by the staff be converted into additional dormitory space. The provision of one toilet for the number of pupils accommodated is hardly ideal, but this is only for night use and the school is equipped with outside facilities for use by the boys during the day.

The rooms and linen appeared to be clean.

Dining Rooms:

The dining rooms appeared to be clean and have ample accommodation for the pupils. The food appeared to be of good quality and of ample quantity. A copy of the diet sheet for the week is attached.

Water Supply:

Water is secured from a creek which has been dammed, and water is also stored in a large cistern. It appeared of good quality and sufficient supply.

Sanitary Conditions:

In general the school was reasonably clean. Kitchen, lavatories, toilets and boiler room, as well as the main part of the building, were inspected and found in good condition. The gymnasium however was badly in need of a good cleaning.

Health:

The Principal informs me that the pupils are now bathed once a week, instead of once every other week. This necessary change was apparently brought about at the suggestion of Dr. Tennant, Medical Superintendent of the Department of Health and Welfare. The pupils appeared to be in good health. There were no pupils in the infirmary at the time of my visit.

R.F. Davey
District Inspector of Indian Schools.

The COMMERCIAL oven as described in the photograph is one that was especially designed by a well known Western bread baker, that would particularly supply the advantage heretofore only available from permanent brick installations.

All ovens are entirely embraced with heat.
All ovens are entirely covered in brick.
The bricks are installed inside on the bottoms, and on the outside for tops and sides.
Under operation this oven becomes entirely heat saturated in 1½ hours from original firing.
Temperatures vary after heat attained at 10 deg. variation, with 375 deg. in the lower, 365 deg. in the middle, and 355 deg. on the top oven.
Higher or lower temperatures can be as easily maintained as desired.

Dear Mr. Arneil:

The news contained in your letter received last evening is not very encouraging in as much as the school has not yet benefited from the items stated to have been spent on the school. The Bake Oven, though asked for nearly a year ago has not been received, the $700 was spent to no advantage, the $500 has not all been spent.

There was $3500, a special grant over and above the regular requisition, which I may say did not get a chance to spend. I did my part by sending in the itemized list of requirements on November 1947. Now a year has gone by and I have so far received nothing to the advantage of the school, except whatever the money spent on the road might be considered as an advantage.

Re the hot water tank, I hope that order has gone in and it can be made an emergency. This is an emergency. I need it and need it badly. Would like to hear from you on this item.

Re: Christie Residential School

In my letter to you of August 17th, 1949, I advised that Father Sheehan, Principal of the Christie School, was of the opinion that the $500.00 available from the appropriation for the School could be spent to the best advantage on further repairs and improvements to the School road and apparently an accountable advance for this purpose was sent to Superintendent Gerrard.

The Reverend Principal, reference Mr. Gerrard's letter of January 5th, attached, has apparently reconsidered and would now prefer to spend approximately $320.00 of the amount for the purchase of fire hose. I wish to refer to the accountable advance in the amount of $500 that is held in the Agency Trust Account for repairs and improvements on the road from Christie school to Opitsat Indian Reserve. It was apparent that the most urgent requirements of the school during the summer months were repairs to the school road; however, since the amount available could not exceed $500, Rev. Sheahan reconsidered this matter and feels that these funds would be used to a better advantage if spent on a fire hose.

Dear Sir,

The Reverend principal of the Clayoquot industrial school has applied to the Department of Public Works for the erection of a wharf in front of the school. The local district engineer of the Department of Public Works has reported stating that he could not recommend the erection of a wharf which would be of service to the school only, inasmuch as it would necessitate an approach of approximately 1400 feet. He suggests as an alternative the provision of a floating boat-house moored close to the shore, into which the dory, used for landing supplies shipped to the school, could be placed when the steamer arrives during the night or in rainy weather.

I have been asked for an expression of opinion as to whether this might be considered urgent work and I shall be glad if you will let me have a report with as little delay as possible as I have nothing before me now from any of our own officers that would enable me to come to a decision.

VICTORIA, B.C., November 24, 1919.

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 17th inst., I would not recommend the construction of a wharf at Kakawis, B.C., because the captain of the C.P.R.SS. PRINCESS MAQUINNA stated that he would be unable to make landings at either of two points where a wharf could be constructed, with a fairly short approach. In addition there is no road to either of these points from the Indian School which is the only settlement that would benefit by the construction of a wharf. To construct a wharf fronting the school house having a depth of 16 feet at low water at its face would necessitate an approach of approximately 1400' in length and I do not consider that this expenditure would be justified in view of the fact that the Department is already maintaining two wharfs at Tofino and Clayoquot respectively, which are both within two miles of this site.

An alternative suggestion would be the provision of a floating boat house moored close to the shore into which the dory used for landing supplies, shipped to the Indian school by the SS. PRINCESS MAQUINNA could be placed at such times as this vessel arrives during the night or in rainy weather and these supplies could then be left in the boat house under shelter until it was convenient for same to be removed to the Indian school. The estimated cost of a boat house of this description is $1400 and I am of opinion that this would meet their needs, assuming that a work of this description would be one coming under the jurisdiction of the Department of Public Works.

Yours obediently,

(SGD) A. F. MITCHELL.
Acting District Engineer.

Eugene D. Lafleur, Esq.,
Chief Engineer, P.M.D.,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your communication bearing date of Dec. 19th which has reference to the construction of a deck or floating boat-house at the Christie Industrial School. The erection of a wharf which would be of service to the School would be a very costly undertaking and would not be used sufficiently to warrant the heavy expenditure. I am therefore strongly of the opinion that a floating boat-house is the only practical solution to the question and then it will be a problem to meet same so as to withstand storms. At this point there is always a heavy swell rolling in during stormy weather as well as very strong tides throughout the year. The successful mooring of a floating boat-house would be the most difficult part of an undertaking of this nature and while it would certainly be a great convenience to the School I would not consider it or sufficient urgency as to necessitate immediate construction and might further add that it is only during the summer months that work of this nature can be successfully carried on at this point.

Secretary.
WHARF: The landing conditions here are not good. It is, owing to the surf, necessary to go ashore in a small boat. The bay is very shallow. When I reached the school the Principal made a long statement, the main points of which are mentioned below.

The Rev. Father in part stated that he very much wants some sort of wharf. He stated that there is very great danger in conveying the children by means of his flat bottom freight boat to the C.P.R. ship. It will of course be understood that the C.P.R. ship must anchor well out in deep water.

The Principal states that accidents have only been narrowly averted during the last two years. He considers that should such an accident happen, there will be great loss of life. The children, he states, get sick boarding the C.P.R. Maquinna. There is a rocky point near the school. At this point he thinks the water would be deep enough for the Maquinna. He goes on to say that YOUNG boys have been out from 12:30 A.M. to 6 A.M. three times to land freight. He tells me that The Right Rev. Bishop Gerald Murray has taken up this question with the Department at Ottawa.

REPORT ON ABOVE: As the construction of a Wharf would involve the Department in considerable expenditure I went into the matter with the greatest care.

At the nearest point to the school the Indian Agent and the Engineer of the Department's boat took eight soundings while I carried on the inspection of the school. It was found that the water is much more shallow than was at first supposed. In a direction W. by S. from the point soundings were taken for a distance of 400 feet. They were in feet 6, 6, 7, 8, 10, 10, 12. It is therefore evident that no wharf could be placed off the nearest point to the school buildings.

Soundings were then taken off the next point. The water here is 15ft deep at a point 30ft from the shore. At about 50ft out the water is 25ft deep. There is then a sudden drop to deep water. For the first 40ft or so the bottom is rock, and piles could not be driven. From 50ft out the water is too deep for piles. A very important note has been suggested by the Captain of a coasting steamer. It is to the effect that for such a wharf to be of any use by such a ship as the Maquinna there would have to be from two to three hundred feet available, where the ship could tie up and still be in deep water. No ship could tie up at a wharf parallel with the coast here, as the place is open to the S.E. winds from the direction of Leonard Islands.

From the result of these soundings, it is quite evident that however much a wharf is required at this school, the fact remains that the construction of such a wharf here is impossible.

The question of a road to the second of the points mentioned above was also looked into. It was found that such a road would in one place have to drop suddenly about 50 feet. This would make the construction a very costly matter. The point is likewise not situated on the school property. A long wharf of 200 to 300 feet off this point would also probably be considered a menace to navigation. It is hard to explain all the above points without a large scale chart; but it may be taken for granted that the construction of a wharf at the Christie Indian Residential School is out of the question from a practical point of view.

Dear Sir,

The Department of Public Works, Victoria, has sent Mr. Mitchell of their staff to inspect the wharf-site at Kakawis. Mr. Mitchell has about finished his work.

In a conversation with him on the subject, he remarked that the wharf at $15,000.00 would be quite expensive. I assured him that I could not take that view of the matter. But a wharf at Kakawis must be considered as being an integral and important part of the institution itself, and playing a most necessary roll in the activities carried on by it. It is its freight and express terminal. Through it pass the mail.

Again, for instance, where other schools have farms which must be equipped with expensive farm machinery and cattle to carry on, products from such a source used at Christie School must pass over the wharf; so that if the region and climate in which our institution is located militate against our procuring the benefits that come from expenditures on a farm, at least, it would seem, we are entitled to expenditures on ways and means that could effect procuring the substitutes for these benefits from being the difficult, laborious and dangerous task it is.

I trust, Mr. Ferrier, that the Department will approve the construction of a wharf at Kakawis.
