Sir,

As instructed, I made an investigation of conditions at Kakawis, in connection with proposed wharf at that place.

During school periods there are about one hundred and twenty-five staff and Indians resident at the school, and I am informed that about 250 tons of general freight are received per annum, while 100 tons of coal were being unloaded on the beach while I was there, representing one year's requirements.

Fronting the school is a sandy beach affording good driving for piles, but, as this beach extends to deep water on a very gradual slope, a wharf with sufficient depth of water to accommodate C.F.R. steamers would have to be of the following dimensions:

Wharfhead, 40 feet x 30 feet;
Approach, 1,050 feet x 12 feet;
With freight shed and landing steps for small boats.

The cost of a wharf at this site, using creosoted piles, would be approximately $20,000.00.

To the North-West of this beach is another smaller sandy beach, where indications also appear favourable for driving piles. At this site a wharf of the following dimensions would be needed:

Wharfhead, 80 feet x 40 feet;
Approach, 630 feet x 12 feet;
Freight shed and landing steps.

The cost of a wharf at this site would be approximately $14,000.00.

A road, 1,200 feet in length, would be required at the latter site built through heavy timber to connect the school with the wharf, and could be built on a gradient of 1 in 30. Northwesternly of the small bay above referred to, deep water gradually approaches much closer to the shore. The beach, however, consists of rock and large boulders, and fronting the beach are considerable bodies of kelp, indicating rock with small probability of affording holding ground for piles.

Kakawis is situated on Deception Channel and any wharf site in the vicinity is subject to the serious disability of being exposed to the direct swells from the open Pacific Ocean via Broken Channel. There are also currents running in Deception Channel at a speed of from two to five knots.

It must, therefore, be anticipated that any wharf constructed would be subjected to considerable impact at times from steamers when making landings, and the maintenance costs of a wharf would, in consequence, be correspondingly increased.

J.P. Forde,
District Engineer P.W.D.
Victoria, B.C.
I have discussed the matter with the Master of C.P.R. s.s. "Princess Norah" who has an intimate knowledge of local conditions and, in his opinion, which I feel sure is correct, landings could be made at a wharf during good weather conditions in the summertime, but during the Fall and Winter months he considers that there would be fairly frequent occasions on which landings would not be possible.

General conditions, are, therefore, unfavourable but if it is considered by the Department of Indian Affairs that the somewhat limited advantages obtainable by building a wharf here would be worth the initial and future maintenance costs which would be involved, I shall be pleased to receive your further instructions in the matter.

Yours obediently,

A.F. MITCHELL,
SR.ASST.ENGINEER.

Comox-Alberni District.

Dear Sir:

After trying every possible method to solve the freight problem at this institution and having met with failure in each instance I have decided that something must be done to obtain a wharf. The steamer comes here every ten days bringing the necessities of life and our freight is always heavy. We must go out in a scow and land the freight on the beach which is always very rough. Invariably the waves break over the boat subjecting everybody and everything to a cold salt water bath. Last week fifty tons of coal came by steamer since no one else would handle it for us. The coal was landed at wharves two and one half miles away. We made twelve trips in our small scow to bring the coal to our beach. The scow would not ride up on the beach so we were compelled to walk in water up to our waists and carry sacks weighing on the average of one hundred and twenty pounds. Some of the sacks had to be thrown from the boat into the water in order to save the scow from going to pieces. These sacks, nine hundred of them, had to be carried some two hundred yards to the bottom of the slip. Every day for a solid week the boys and myself were wet all day. It looked like old slave days and that is a common occurrence every boat day.

I have obtained estimates from a very good man who has had experience in building wharves along this particular coast. He puts the cost at five thousand dollars. I would therefore appeal to the Department to do something for us to alleviate this back breaking job which is a menace to life and good health. Hoping to hear from you very favourably in the near future, I am,

Yours respectfully,

[Signature]

Reverend Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 28th ultimo, requesting that a grant be provided to cover the cost of building a wharf at the Christie Indian Residential School.

The question of building a wharf at your school has been brought to the Department's attention on several occasions in the past. In 1935, the Senior Assistant Engineer of the Public Works Department reported regarding a wharf; and, for your information, I enclose copy of this report.

You will note that, in spite of the large expenditure that would be involved, the Engineer considered general conditions were unfavourable. Under these circumstances, the Department is not prepared to consider the erection of a wharf at the Christie School.

It has been suggested that, if a warehouse was built at Tofino, the C. P. R. boat could discharge all freight for the Christie School at that point and place same in the warehouse. In order to transport the freight from Tofino to the school, it would be necessary to employ a suitable flat-bottomed snow, which could be employed by one of the school launches and arranged in such a manner as to have the snow reach the school at high tide, so that it could be brought in as close to the shore as possible. When the tide went out, the snow could be unloaded. The Department realizes that it is necessary for the Christie School to buy their supplies in advance, and, if the suggestion made in this letter is feasible, the freight could be brought from Tofino on those days when weather conditions are suitable.

A copy of this letter is being forwarded to the Indian Agent, and he is being instructed to visit the Christie School at an early date and discuss with you the Department's suggestion for handling the freight. If the plan as outlined could be put into effect, the Agent and yourself should obtain estimates of the cost of erecting a warehouse at Tofino and the purchase of a suitable flat-bottomed snow. This information should then be forwarded for the Department's consideration.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Deputy Superintendent General.

Rev. Bertrand McLoughlin, O.S.B.,
Principal,
Christie Indian Residential School,
Kakawin, B.C.
I have read all your former communications subject of a proposed wharf and am therefore familiar with all the objections hitherto brought up which militate against it.

Now, therefore, I am going to ask the Department to grant us the sum of $3000.00 with which to construct a wharf, landing platform, and a road from the wharf point to the School. This is less than half what the Department had at one time estimated this work would cost. I have these figures from practical men here on the bay and from the parties who are now constructing the dock at Ahousat. I would propose that a wharf be built following plans and specifications of the Ahousat wharf with modifications to suit local conditions.

I will state, for your information, that my father was a building contractor and that I have, all my life, lived in an atmosphere of construction work. And for this particular type of work I will say also that for forty years I have lived on the Ocean shore and I understand and am very familiar with ocean currents, etc. Though I am a priest for nearly twenty-five years, I have been very busy building up four parishes and assisted in the construction of buildings at our Monastery to the value of over four hundred thousand dollars. I mention this because I wish you to realize that I do consider my opinion of some value when it comes to matters of this kind.

I earnestly pray that you will, at this time, grant a favourable hearing on this very important matter, and after receiving this assurance from you I will be pleased to give you more details of what we have in mind.

Believe me, dear Sir, to be,

Gratefully yours,

Sir:

I have the honour to communicate with the Department re proposed wharf or landing or means of communication between Christie School and Tofino, B.C.

In this connection, one of the chief difficulties that is experienced at Christie School is the landing of pupils, as the boat often reaches this point at night. It readily can be seen that it is extremely difficult to take a lot of children ashore through breaking surf. This condition exists quite frequently on the beach in front of Christie School. Freight is also very difficult to land at times, and much has been written the Department re this matter. It is felt that the Department is fully aware of the difficulties and the danger of this landing, and the following suggestions are respectfully submitted, and have been arrived at after much thought and many surveys of the district.

The writer has observed conditions at this point for many years, and it appears that there is only one satisfactory way to overcome these difficulties. A wharf is obviously out of the question. Its construction would of necessity cost a great deal, and the upkeep would be prohibitive. There is in addition the fact that it is very difficult to drive piles in that locality, as the holding ground is not sufficiently deep above bed rock. The Department's suggestion of a warehouse at Tofino and a flat-bottomed boat or scow to be landed on the beach at high tide, is a very good one, but would not be practical in winter, when south east gales drive directly on this beach and raise a surf that is sometimes four and five feet high. The writer has several times attempted to land with a boat or canoe and found it impossible to do so, and in several instances officers of the Department have
been precipitated into the water. There is, however, a sheltered wharf that is used by the Indians of the Opitsaht Reserve, and a trail that is approximately twenty minutes walk from the wharf to the school. This trail has been brushed out and is planked for nearly the entire distance. The wharf, however, at the reserve end would need repairs. This would be, in the writer's opinion, the only safe way to land children at the school safely at all times of the year. The trail could be broadened out and a light truck purchased for transporting school freight there. The wharf on the reserve is approximately five minutes by launch from the Tofino wharf. There is a freight shed on the government wharf at Tofino that could house the goods going to Christie School, and same could be taken over with the existing equipment that the school has, by launch, in daylight, and transported from the wharf on the reserve to Christie School.

The rough sketch enclosed will serve to illustrate the surrounding district, and the relative distances, although it is not drawn to scale.

One other fact to be borne in mind is that once this trail was widened to a sufficient width to allow a truck to pass over it, the upkeep would be very small and all people engaged in the shipping business on the West Coast unanimously agree that it would be impossible, on the other hand, to hold a pile dock in front of the school, thereby proving the contention that it is impossible to build and maintain such a dock without an enormous expenditure. The writer feels that the present suggestion has never been passed to the Department for consideration, and forwards same respectfully, in no way wishing to cloud other plans that are at present under consideration, but feeling that the Department should know conditions as they exist at Christie School and the surrounding district.

Your obedient servant,

H. P. Nightingale,
Acting Indian Agent.

Dear Sir,

For forty years the Fathers, Sisters, Teaching Staff, the Children, and all callers at Christie Indian Residential School have been inconvenienced, and in many cases their lives have been endangered, in an effort to make a landing on the shores at Kakawis.

The dangerous and stupendous task of handling freight at this school can only be appreciated by those who have had to do this throughout all these years. But I hardly deem it necessary to make mention of this for the Department has long ago been cognizant of these facts. I am positive that to their way of thinking, as surely as it is ours, a wharf at this institution has been a long-felt need.

I regret to say that almost every principal who has been in charge here, has, with the greatest reluctance, been compelled to give up efforts to secure financial assistance from the Canadian Government, for this, so worthy and so necessary a cause.

I was an assistant to Fr. Charles Moser seventeen years ago, and I felt at that time, as I do now, that if I were placed in charge, a wharf would be the one big thing for which I would strive. I deem it absolutely cruel to compel intelligent men and women to submit to the crude and primitive manner of making landings at this Institution.

As Religious, we have been, and still are, willing to give all that we have, sacrifice our homes and friends and the comforts of life that we might bring the light of Christianity and the boon of Civilization to these poor unfortunate Indians. All this, to the end that they might some day learn to live cleaner and better lives and become useful and self-sustaining citizens of this Great Country.

Dear Sir:

I beg to refer to your letter of August 15th regarding representations made to the Department for the construction of a wharf, landing platform and a road from the wharf to Christie Indian Residential School at Kakawis, West Coast Agency. This matter was referred to Indian Agent Ashbridge and I am forwarding herewith his report dated September 16th for your information.

The main objection to constructing a wharf at Kakawis is that the site on which it is proposed to construct the wharf is too exposed to the weather and there does not appear to be a suitable site in the vicinity that is not so exposed. There was an examination of this site in 1932 by the senior assistant engineer of the Department of Public Works, who considered the general conditions unfavorable for the construction of a wharf; these conditions still exist and, I consider it would be unwise to proceed with such an undertaking in view of the reports of those who have made an examination of the conditions on the ground and were qualified to do so.

From the information before me, it would appear that the construction of a road from Opitsaht Reserve, where there is a wharf, to Christie School would meet the situation. This wharf is in sheltered water, is used by the Indians of the Opitsaht Band and is connected by trail to Christie School. It has been suggested that the proposed road follow closely the location of this trail and that it be wide wide enough to admit of the use of a light truck. The supplies for the school would continue to be landed at Torino and transported by the school launch to the Opitsaht wharf and thence by truck to the school. I am inclined to favor these alternative arrangements and would recommend that an engineer of the Dominion Water and Power Branch be instructed to make a survey of the proposed road and submit a report and an estimate of the cost.

Yours faithfully,

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Sir:

I have the honour to refer to your letter of October 4th, 1937, with respect to the wharf at Opitsat Reserve, and to report the findings of my inspection of this wharf, and roadway leading to Christie School, on my last visit there on October 14th.

**Wharf:** Built by the Department with Indian labor, March, 1937. Not yet completed, requires an extra vent to bring out to deep water. Estimated cost to complete $300. The channel is narrow and shallow and only boats with shallow draft can land at wharf.

**Roadway to School:** This trail follows near the beach from Opitsat Reserve to Christie School, and is roughly about 1 1/3 miles in length. For 2 thirds of the way a good trail could be made, but nearing the school there are two bad places where extensive bridging would have to be done in order to make a suitable road for a truck. The whole distance is fairly heavily timbered.

Before attempting to put in a roadway, it would be advisable to have a surveyor report on it, as it may be possible to find a better grade. The expense of building a roadway suitable for a truck over the present trail would be very heavy, owing to the necessity of bridging and planking.

Before attempting to place a wharf near the school, or build a roadway from Opitsat I would respectfully recommend that the whole be most thoroughly surveyed, as in either case the expense would be great. The fact of the school being old, leaving a possibility of its having to be rebuilt, should also be considered, as in this event it would not be advisable to put another school on such an inaccessible site.

MEMORANDUM

From: A. Halkett, Asst. Engineer, to J.P. Forde, Dist. Engineer.

Ref.: NAKAWIS BAY, Comox-Alberni District.

As instructed I visited the Industrial School for Indian children at Nakawis Bay, Clayoquot Sound, West Coast of Vancouver Island, on the 26th ultimo, for the purpose of looking into the request made by the school authorities for a wharf to be built near their school.

I saw the school principal, as instructed, who took us to a shallow bay about one-half mile north of the school in Deception Channel, where he had been advised that a suitable wharf could be built to accommodate the coastal steamers serving this part of the Coast.

A survey of the bay showed that a wharf could be constructed with sufficient depth of water for the largest of the coastal steamers at a distance of 220 ft. from the shore. During the last 20 years various requests have come to the Department from this school for a wharf and three different sites have been surveyed, but owing to one reason or another, principally as being unsuitable owing to prevailing winds and adverse currents for the steamer landings, the wharf was not built. Having this in mind I made a point of showing the plan of the bay with a drawing of the wharf to Captain Robert Thomson of the "PRINCESS NORAH", and asked his opinion in regard to making a landing here should a wharf be constructed. Both from an examination of the plan and observations made since when in the vicinity of the bay, Captain Thomson reports favourably on the site that a landing could be made here by the C.P.R. Coastal Steamers unless under very abnormal weather conditions.

There is no public road here and a private road would have to be made through heavily wooded land for a distance of about one-half mile to connect the school with the wharf by land.

The school has been a port of call for the C.P.R. Coastal Steamers for many years, making three calls each month. Much freight is handled and only a boat landing is made, when passengers and freight have to be transferred to shore by launch or canoe. There have been occasions when near fatalities have occurred by the capsizing of canoes precipitating the passengers into the water, according to the information furnished me by the school principal.

An estimate of cost for wharf 100'x40', approach 180'x14', and float 40'x16', with freight shed, gangway, etc., using creosoted piles throughout, would be $9,000.00.

"A. Halkett"

Asst. Engineer.

MEMORANDUM:

Deputy Minister:

I am in receipt of Mr. Jackson's memorandum of December 6 in connection with the request for the construction of a wharf in front of the Indian Residential School at Kakawis, B.C.

While the wharf might be used by some of the Indians residing in the locality, it would be almost totally required by the management of the Christie Residential School. As a consequence, if the wharf were built, the expense would have to be assumed by this Department, as I consider it unlikely that the Public Works Department would construct it. However, there can be no possible objection to endeavouring to have them do so.

At the Christie School there are 110 pupils and a staff of 14. All food, clothing, and other requirements of the school have to be brought in by boat, as there are no local stores. It is located on the west coast of Vancouver Island on a site exposed to the Pacific Ocean. During many years past, successive Principals have directed our attention to the fact that weather conditions make the handling of freight both a dangerous and stupendous task. There is no doubt that a wharf is extremely necessary for this school.

MEMORANDUM:
From: A.Halkett, Asst. Engineer, to J.F.Forde, District Engineer.
Reference: KAKAWIS BAY, Comox-Alberni District.

As instructed, I visited the Industrial School for Indian children at Kakawis Bay, Clayoquot Sound, West Coast of Vancouver Island on the 20th ultimo for the purpose of looking into the request made by the school authorities for a wharf to be built near their school.

I saw the school principal, as instructed, who took us to a shallow bay about one-half mile North of the school in Deception Channel where he had been advised that a suitable wharf could be built to accommodate the coastal steamers serving this part of the Coast.

A survey of the bay showed that a wharf could be constructed with a sufficient depth of water for the largest of the coastal steamers at a distance of 220-feet from the shore. During the last 30 years various requests have come to the Department from this school for a wharf and three different sites have been surveyed but owing to one reason or another, principally as being unsuitable owing to prevailing winds and adverse currents for the steamer landings, the wharf was not built. Having this in mind, I made a point of showing the plan of the bay with a drawing of the wharf to Capt. Robert Thomson of the "Princess Norah" and asked his opinion in regard to making a landing here should a wharf be constructed. Both from an examination of the plan and observations made since then in the vicinity of the bay Capt. Thomson reports favourably on the site, that a landing could be made here by the C.P.R. Coastal Steamers unless under very abnormal weather conditions.

There is no public road here and a private road would have to be made through heavily wooded land for a distance of about 1/2 mile to connect the school with the wharf by land.

The school has been a port of call for the C.P.R. coastal steamers for many years, making three calls each month. Much freight is handled and only a boat landing is made, when passengers and freight have to be transferred to shore by launch or canoe. There have been occasions when near fatalities have occurred by the capsizing of canoes, precipitating the passengers into the water, according to the information furnished me by the school principal.

An estimate of cost for wharf, 100' x 40', approach, 180' x 14', and float, 40' x 16', with freight shed, gangway, etc., using creosoted piles throughout, will be $9,000.00.

'A.Halkett'
Asst. Engineer.

Dear Sirs:

Since my visit to Ottawa last fall, and on my return to Christie School, I have been frequently asked what progress was being made relative to a wharf at Kakawis. My answer invariably was that we were asked to wait until April when the matter would be taken up and decided upon.

When I personally interviewed the Department I had two very important requests to make. The one referred to a wharf and the other to a building for Manual Training. You have letters on file in reference to these projects. I was told that it might be impossible to grant both of them at the same time.

If I were to choose between the two I would be at a loss to consider which the more important. For our boys to learn how to repair engines, make boats and bridges and build their simple dwellings is a very important feature in their educational development and in their future self-maintenance.

Could I suggest that the Government reimburse us next year if we, at this time, construct the building in lieu of the fact that you would set aside, at once, the money necessary for a wharf? A Manual Training shop is a direct benefit to the boys, a wharf an absolute necessity for the entire school and an asset to all who have any interests at Kakawis.

I notice that the Government has already consented to invest twice the amount we ask for a similar project at Zeballos, B.C. This project is but an infant and might petrify before it has two legs to stand on, and yet men will urge the Government to invest thousands of dollars, and they themselves are willing to throw in all they have, and cast the die for the possible gain of a few paltry dollars. Let us at
least compare the development of character in the natives and the utility of the projects necessary for this, to that of a purely commercial idea. In the long run, remuneration for this will be ample.

So, dear sirs, again we plead with you not to turn a deaf ear to our needs, but grant us, under the exercise of your good and far-sighted discretion, these two most urgent requests.

Sincerely yours,

(Sgd.) Hildebrand Melchior

CHRISTIE RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL:

The school authorities are putting in a float landing and building a trail, to improve facilities for landing people and supplies. While some doubt exists as to the life of the float during the winter storms, the efforts of the principal and staff are commendable, and reflect great credit on those who have assisted with the work.

XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX
Christie Indian Residential School
Kakawin, B.C.
Sept. 6th, 1938

Mr. Philip Paclan,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Paclan:

In the estimates made by Mr. Indian Agent Ashbridge and myself, we made out a few days ago some track about which I think it advisable to write to you. This track, if obtained, is to be laid between the School and the present float which is located where the projected wharf may be built. The main objection which may be raised against supplying this track is that the wharf may never be built as it has not been definitely proved that a wharf can be constructed at this or any other point. The reply is that even if a wharf is never built, the track is really necessary—necessary in the sense that it will eliminate a great deal of hard work and danger.

As you are aware, passengers and freight are now taken from the C.P.R. steamer, several hundred yards from shore, put into one of our boats, brought nearer to the shore and then passengers as well as freight are carried on the boat's bank to the beach. The freight has to be carried a considerable distance to a truck which hauls it up in a hill to its destination. Transferring from the steamer to our boat and carrying from our boat through the water to the shore are dangerous and difficult operations if the sea is at all rough. Considerable loss is incurred for instance when flour has thus to be transported in the rain. Other merchandise has been dropped and lost or damaged in the sea. One Venerable Mother Provincial fell in far from shore and was only just rescued. I need not describe what is likely to happen in a storm. Should the rails not be granted, the Will the right put it into my mind to suggest to one of the men that, when the next Official from Ottawa comes, there be an unavoidable accident whereby the said visitor be able to compare his experiences with those of the Mother Provincial.

Father Hildebrand believed, as did others, that a wharf might be constructed at a certain point and, to see whether this were feasible or not, had a float built at this point. It is argued that, if this float stands up against the winter tides and storms, a much more strongly built wharf will do the same. Let us suppose that no wharf can be built. Well, the float or a landing place will be of great use to us. Passengers and freight can be brought from the steamer to this place without the long planks back ride through the water. The freight can be transferred from the boat to the truck, awaiting at the landing, and hauled by motor over the rails to the School. This truck could be covered to protect flour, etc., against the rain. A great deal of hard and dangerous work would thus be eliminated. I might add that, as there is no place for walks, the children are often taken for a ride Sunday afternoon on the school boat. We have already found the float a great advantage in loading and unloading the children.

A good start has already been made on the trail. A clearing, about 10-12 feet wide, has been cut through the woods from the School to the float and all stumps have been removed. We still have a good deal of levelling and grading to do. The weather and the fact that all has to be done by hand (we have no tractor, horse, ploughs or scrapers) make this slow work but we are going ahead.

In order to stand a better chance of getting the rails, we have not put several other items into the estimates. Something should be done; I helped unload 6 tons of freight the other day, and can imagine what the landing of 30 tons of coal means.

I felt that these things should be brought to your attention so that you would understand why we asked for rails even though it is not certain that a real wharf can be built.
Christie Indian Residential School

Kakawis, B.C.

Can a wharf be built—one that will stand up? I do not know. The man who built the float and who has built several wharves in the neighbourhood believes that a satisfactory wharf can be built. I do not know enough about these matters or about the storms and tides here to say.

Shortly before I left the Cariboo School, you kindly sent us some footballs and volley balls. I felt like writing to you but felt that that might be rather impolite. The covers were not very good and the bladders were evidently old stock with small holes in them. You will have to watch the suppliers next time!

With kind personal regards,

Yours truly,

G. F.

P.S. Father Turner, who was here at the time, tells me that a Road Engineer approved of the location chosen and said that the Engineer said that a satisfactory wharf could be built there.

Dear Dr. McGill:

May I speak to you frankly? I think that your having Indians from various provinces broadcast to all Canadians was a master stroke. The enclosed photograph will indicate they are doing our bit. I come from a family of actors and I thought that good plays might help our pupils to speak good English and to talk distinctly. Competent critics (your Inspector of Schools included) show that my effort was not in vain. And, moreover, take a look at these boys (our presentation of Cardinal Wiseman's 2½ hours "Hidden Gun"), have I fed them well? Are they happy?

I have done my share and I ask you to do the same. Will you please have your Department use their imagination in lieu of their knowledge? I would welcome an official of the Department here. The facts: I was in charge of the Cariboo School for over 7 years. In officially, I was at the Kamloops and other schools... The point is this: Kamloops Mission, Cariboo, Lytton, Sardis, etc., have their large pupilage and their farms. We have a small pupilage here and RISK with no possible farm or herd. We have not only to buy what those schools produce but we have to pay freight on it. I could add more but think that this will suggest that we deserve special treatment may I add this? The C.P.R. boat stops away out. Our motor boat meets it and proceeds to low water. Canoes then take off passengers and freight. The canoes stop and our men and I pack passengers and freight through the water on our backs. If you, the Pope or the King come, the procedure will be the same. We DESERVE consideration. So, if a cut must come, do not make a general cut but use your knowledge or imagination. If they have been too frank, well I am from Calgary and crave your indulgence.

Yours very truly,

PORT ALBERNI, B.C.

Re. Rhoda Webster & Kakawis School.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter re the recent protest made by me to the admission of the above girl to the Kakawis School, and also copy of your letter to Rev. B. McLaughlin of that school.

I note that you ask Father McLaughlin to "consult" with me re the case and let you know the conclusions we both arrive at.

Father McLaughlin 'phoned me today, but his conversation was far from being in the nature of a consultation. I pointed out to him that Webster was Protestant, was baptized into the United Church membership, was educated at this school and that his brother was at present a member of this school, also that Webster had recently voluntarily asked me to baptize his youngest child. Father McLaughlin stated that Webster was a Catholic, that his father was a Catholic and that all the Indians on the Coast including the Ahousaht Band were Catholics. I asked him to repeat this statement, which he did. I then said that, in his opinion, this school had absolutely no right of existence, and was not entitled to any Indian pupils whatever. He said that that was true, and this statement he also repeated.

Under the circumstances, and in face of the emphatically expressed opinion of the Father that this school has no right of existence on the Coast, you can conceive how impossible it is for us to come to any amicable agreement. I feel that this matter of pupilage is one that can only be definitely settled by an authoritative pronouncement by the Department of Indian Affairs. I have no wish to attempt to enter into any further negotiations with the Kakawis school as it is obviously considered by them that this school is entitled to no rights and privileges whatever.

Yours very truly,

A. E. Caldwell,

Principal.

Re Rhoda Webster.

Dear Sir,

In the matter of the admittance of the above child to residential school attendance, decision was deferred by the Department until July of this year.

May I request that the Department again be made cognizant of the facts in connection with this case.

Peter Webster, the father, under the name of Peter Samson, was admitted to the Ahousaht school at the age of 13, on Jan 19th 1920, not having previously attended any other school. His brother, Andrew Webster, was admitted to this school on July 2nd 1929. He is still attending the school at the age of 15.

Peter Webster, or Samson, was discharged from this school on Dec. 31st 1922.

Peter Webster is a Protestant. His present wife is Catholic. There are three children of the marriage to date, and the decision in this case will affect the other children.

Webster signified his intention to apply for admission of the girl Rhoda to the Ahousaht school last year, and it was only the violent protest of his wife, to which protest the writer was witness, that induced the father to make application for Rhoda's admission to the Christie School.

That Peter Webster has not changed his religion is indicated by the fact that he personally requested the baptism of his latest child, Jessie, into the Protestant faith, and the baptism was performed November 8th 1936.

Former decisions of disputes of this nature by the Department have been against this school, attention being called to the provisions of the Indian Act as stated by Sec. IO (2).

May I submit that the facts of the above case designate the above child a Protestant child within the meaning of the Indian Act.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

May I add that the father Peter Webster has stated to me that it is the intention of his wife to send the female children to the Christie School and the male children to the Ahousaht School. I am sure that the Department will decide that this is a practice that should not be encouraged, in the interests of Indian family unity.

Dear Sir:

Some of the applicants here enclosed are according to the rules of the department below school age. These children have been brought to us by their guardians without our having sought them. We have even been reluctant to admit them owing to the extra care and attention that has to be given to young children. In these cases, either the father, mother or both are dead. Sometimes the father and mother are living apart and often the children are in the care of the old grandparents who can ill afford to care for them.

Such are the cases under consideration and we have been moved by charity to admit them to our school in the hope that you will place them on the per capita grant in view of the extra care and attention that has to be given. We have noticed your have granted this request before.

Yours very sincerely,

Hildebrand Melchior
Rev. Hildebrand Melchior, O.S.B.
Principal

P.S.

I should have made some mention also, relative to the discharge age limit of children. Some say the age is sixteen, other eighteen. The Sisters and the faculty are all agreed that sixteen would be a reasonable age at which to discharge boys. We are making an earnest request, however, that girls be retained at the school until they are eighteen. There are very serious reasons for this, namely, that as soon as a girl leaves school at any age she becomes the prey of men seeking her in marriage, and anyone knows that the life of these children is difficult enough after wedding in maturity. Please grant us the permission to retain all girls until they have attained their eighteenth year.

H.M.

Dear Sir,

I was born on American side my farther was first Indian Agent on American Indian reservation, my mother was B.C. Indian woman, when seven years old. I was sent to Spanish school six miles from Victoria. Have been here ever since.

30 years ago I took Indian wife, first born was a girl, second a boy, who at 3 years died away. Sometimes, got mixing around with American Indians, when we were visiting or friends on American side, a boy was born to her, she died six weeks after her baby was born. I have taken care of the boy ever since his was born. Left my wife 3 years ago, she was jealous of every woman I happen to look at she pleaded to let her have the boy for a while, she promised that she would not send him to school as he is not healthy on account that when only two years old a heavy stick struck him on the side of his head it almost killed him, he has no memory as he had bad blood in his brain.
and Doctor's advice was not to send him to school. This summer while I was at Kyquet fishing, she sent the boy to school at Claguet Indian School. Now that boy's name was born on American side, and also his father was American Indian. He has inherited from his parents a property, and although his name is not yet on the papers, he receives money from timber on his property. His father died 5 or 6 years ago. The boy is now 12 years old, and Dan is his guardian. Dan is a white man, raised among white people, who went to white school, and all Agents always said that I was a white man that my grand son was white and any white and Indian Agent said Indian Department had nothing to do with us. None of the Indians would ever give my grand son or my wife any medicine when sick, and why do they now want to keep that boy in that Indian school among these Indians boys, who are some of them rotten with discipline and only 3 cents for all the boys.
It seems that we are not white any more. The C. priest and Indian Agent seem to be forced to have that boy in school. The C. priest would not even let me see the boy or let him come on my boat, and I love that boy as my own as I got no children, and I am going to adopt him. I will never forget how that C. priest treated me. He treated me as if I was a wild animal. I was even ordered to pull my anchor up and leave in front of the school. Now I have been ordered to have the boy on American side to sign in on his property not later than May 1938, and how am I going to take an American side if C. priest is doing his best at Lagrange Indian school? I think you see that C. priest is wrong in keeping that boy there. He can not be Canadian and cannot hold his land on American side and the poor boy will land that land he becomes a man of no status on this side he will have nothing enclosed you will find last payment on his timber please returned. The boy's name Bertrand Webster, his grand mother's name Jennie Willie unlettered Indian woman.
I belong to Church of England and can see my feelings to see my grand son in that private school. Hope you will understand that it will be the boys advantage to be an American Indian as he will be sure to get more property from his uncles and grandparents on American side. Hope to hear from you soon.

Yours Very Respectfully,

PORT ALBERNI, B.C. Re Rhoda Webster.

Dear Sir,

May I enquire as to what decision has been made by the Department in the matter of the above child. She is residing in the Ahousaht Village and will be eight years old on April 13th next.

In view of the fact that the father, Peter Webster, has declared himself before you as being Protestant, and that, while it is his wife's desire that the children should be entered in a Catholic school, it is the father's own desire that they should be educated in a Protestant school, I cannot see where there should be any great difficulty in determining the case.

There are increasing number of marriages between Catholics and Protestants on the Coast, and in every case where a male Protestant has married a female Catholic, a promise has been extracted from the wife that the children shall be sent to a Catholic school. I have made no attempt to confuse the situation as designated by Section 10 of the Indian Act, and I have refused application for entrance of children to this school where the father of the applicant has been Catholic, but it is obviously important to the continuance of Protestant pupilage on the West Coast, that a definite decision should be made in a case, such as the one now in question, where the father is definitely Protestant.

I should be glad to have this matter cleared up.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Mr. Ashbridge,

When we called at the Jimmy John house on Monday, January 15th to make arrangements for the children to leave for Victoria, it was found that Mr. John had just secured employment with the D. W. Thomas Wholesale Jeweler. Due to Mr. John's inability in the past to cooperate with his employers for any length of time, it was felt that the children should be sent to the Christie Indian Reservation School in spite of the change in the financial situation.

However, Mr. D. W. Thomas came to our office with Mr. John and personally guaranteed that he would pay rent for the family and also give Mr. John a salary of $20.00 per week for a period of a year. Since the entire business is a seasonal one and it is quite possible that the company may not be able to continue business after June or Mr. John may not be able to produce the necessary work, we do not feel entirely satisfied regarding Mr. John's future independence.

In view of the above, do you feel that we are justified in allowing the children to remain with their parents? If so, would it be possible to return them to the Reservation later, in case the family had to again seek assistance from the King County Welfare Department?

Would you please notify us regarding this, and upon receipt of your reply, we will return the draft at once.

Yours very truly,

Dear Mr. Ashbridge:

Recently I employed Willie Johns on a yearly basis to carve for me and just a few days ago I learned that the welfare department of this city had been negotiating with you and that all arrangements had been made to return the five older children to be put in school on Vancouver Island. This action was of course the result of the families need for welfare assistance and to the rather deplorable conditions under which they were living. Without knowing anything about all this my immediate thought was to move the family into better quarters. This I have done. The children are in school getting along nicely and I can guarantee that the father's employment will be steady. Under these circumstances the welfare department said they would recommend to you that we keep the family together. Mr. Johns is teaching his boys the art of carving and they are making splendid progress. They are of course not working for me but merely practicing at home and are also getting considerable help in designing and coloring at school. Of course no one can tell what the future holds and my only concern is that should all these bright prospects fall through that there will be in such an event the same opportunity for the children to be put in your school up there. My opinion is that the only thing that would bring such a situation would be the death or incapacity of the father. I should be glad to hear from you in regard to the above.

I am very much interested in developing Indian art craft and I am told that the very best baskets in the Northwest are made by your Vancouver Island Indians. Any information that you may be able to give me regarding sources will be very much appreciated.

I have often thought of making a trip up the west coast of Vancouver Island and hope to be able to do so this coming summer in which case I shall make it a point to call on you.

Very sincerely yours,

Dear Mr. Ashbridge:

Referring to previous correspondence, we wish to advise you, that Mr. Jimmie John, Indian, has again returned to Seattle and applied for assistance. He is living with the entire family in the same shack which he had in 1936. The children have all been ill from a diet of fish heads, and one of the boys was in King County Hospital for a short time. The eight members of the family are sleeping in two small bunks.

Mr. John stated that a change had been made on the reservation which prevented the family from remaining. It was impossible to determine just what he meant, although he mentioned something about land being sold.

The four boys have been enrolled in a public grade school where they are all in the Adjustment Class.

Would it be possible for the family to return to Port Alberni? There seems to be no means by which Mr. John can support his family, here. They are living in almost unbelievable squalor, and it seems that the children at least should be removed.

Please inform us whether the family may be returned to the reservation, and if so are you able to meet the expense of transportation.

Sir:

I have the honour to request the advice of the Department in the matter of truant children of this Agency, and to enclose herewith correspondence relating to same.

Jimmy John, age 48, of the Moachaht Band, is a first class wood carver, and according to available records here went to Seattle, U.S.A., and has remained there continuously since 1933.

Four of his children were pupils at the Christie Residential School, and last year I had much difficulty in having them returned to school. Jimmy John has again kept his children at Seattle and refuses to send them back, having obtained work there and presumably a home for his family, being assisted in this by Mr. Dell W. Thomas, whose letter I attach.

The Welfare Department of Seattle has given me every assistance in this matter, but apparently Jimmy John is evading them, although he periodically applies to them for assistance.

In view of this, I would respectfully request information and advice as to the status of this man, and the advisability of returning the children to Canada.

I feel I should advise the Department that the prospects of gainful employment for Jimmy John in Canada are negligible and he and his family, if re-admitted, would automatically become a charge against the Department.

Your obedient servant,

P. B. Ashbridge,
Indian Agent.

Sir:

I have the honour to refer to your letter of December 17, 1937, regarding admission to school of Rhoda Webster, Ahousaht Band, and to request the decision of the Department as to which school she should be admitted.

In an interview with Peter Webster, father of this girl, he stated that it was his wish that she be admitted to Ahousaht Residential School, and that he was a Protestant.

Unfortunately, due to his wife being Catholic, some friction has occurred between the Principals of the two schools, but both Principals, and also the parents, are willing to abide by the decision of the Department, which is respectfully requested.

March 31st, 1938.

I, Peter Webster, of the Village of Ahousaht, British Columbia, hereby state, in the matter of the attendance of my daughter, Rhoda, at residential school:

1. That I subscribe to the Protestant religion, being a member of the United Church of Canada.

2. That it is my wish to have my children brought up in the Protestant faith.

3. That I have so informed the Indian Agent, Mr. Ashbridge, on at least two occasions, at formal enquiries for the information of the Indian Department in the matter.

4. That my wife belongs to the Catholic faith, and wishes the children brought up in that faith.

5. That I wish the Department to make a definite decision in the matter of the attendance of my daughter, Rhoda, at residential school, in order that my wife will be satisfied and no family trouble caused.

6. That I was persuaded by my wife to enter the child in the Catholic school, after I had answered to leave the matter of her school attendance to the decision of the Indian Department.

7. That the girl, Rhoda, is eight years old, and it is my desire to have her admitted to the Protestant School at Ahousaht immediately, as we find it difficult under the present financial circumstances, to support her at home.

8. That I know that the department has reserved decision until July 1st of this year. That, if enquiry is made again after that date, I can only repeat the information I have given the Indian Agent before, as noted above.

Signed,

(Pete Webster)

Dear Sir:

This is to find out why the Indian boy ROBERT MARTIN of Catholic parents who desire him to attend Kakawis Indian Residential School is by a recent ruling of the department not permitted to go there despite the fact that under the Indian Act he is too young to be discharged from school? There is no question of his being needed by the father as his brother Simon is already at the father's disposal.

Please note however that this letter is not written in any contentious spirit. I know full well the department is beset with many intricate difficulties that no laws however wise could entirely solve but the various methods of bribing Catholic Indian parents to take out affidavits that their children are not Catholics etc., etc., call for serious attention. This is a case typical of several others and apparently the department simply rules that nothing be done instead of ruling that the child be sent where he should have been sent several years ago. I have all the documents in this case but I am not sending them on immediately because I still desire to spare you any avoidable embarrassment. Is there some hidden factor in this particular case?

Wishing you a very happy new year I remain

Sincerely Yours,

Sir:

I have the honour to submit for the Department's approval the request of the Reverend Principal of Christie Residential School to retain for a further year the following pupils, and to quote his observations on each pupil, as follows:

188-Frank Charlie. "This boy has studied hard even in his free time and wishes to take up grade IX work. Inspector Barry examined him and wrote a letter to the Inspector of High Schools strongly urging that this boy be granted an additional year. I would add that this boy had a rather bad name during the preceding year but that he has shown great improvement since I came. Father Tunner says that he is an entirely different boy. If we can bring good influence to bear on him for another year, there is a great chance that he will be a better man on the reserve than he would be without this special care."

254-Charlie Chippie. "This boy is dull and has had very little schooling. Another year would be of benefit to him."

0194-Maggie Marshall-"The girl, her parents and I request that she remain here for another year. She is not a bad girl but she appears to be attractive and I believe that it would be dangerous to discharge her. I strongly recommend that she be permitted to stay.

0195-Ida Swan. "I have not asked the girl but her father and I request that she be allowed to remain here for a year. She has no mother and her father is said to be a heavy drinker and unable to look after her. She is not a bad girl but, with no home-protection, she would be a worry to me if she remained at home."

I would respectfully recommend that this request be approved.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 5th instant with reference to Bob Martin.

In regard to this boy I may say that on November 30, 1938, Indian Agent Ashbridge forwarded to the Department an application for his admission to the Christie residential school. In regard to the application the Agent wrote as follows:

"With regard to Robert Martin, this boy has been for the past seven years a pupil at Ahousaht School. For some reason he was baptized by the United Church minister and entered at Ahousaht, whereas his parents are both Catholic, and who at this late date now wish to have him transferred.

"When at Ahousaht recently, I spoke to Mr. Caldwell, the Principal, and he has no objection to this transfer.

"I would respectfully recommend that this application be approved."

In official letter of December 7, 1938, Indian Agent Ashbridge was informed that the Department approved the admission of Robert Martin to the Christie residential school. In view of the above correspondence the Department was under the impression that the boy had been admitted to the Christie school. I am not exactly certain from the contents of your letter whether or not he is at the school but if he is there is no necessity for any further action as his admission has been officially approved.

Yours truly,

Rev. H. J. Sorensen, O.M.I.,
Christie Indian Residential School,
Kakawin, B. C.

Chief, Training Division.
Christie Indian Residential School
Kakawin, B.C. February 5th, 1939

Department of Mines and Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Gentlemen:

As the Catholic missionary in charge of the Indian missions on the West Coast of Vancouver Island, I respectfully request that you reconsider your recent decision in the case of Bob Martin as I believe that, when you gave your decision, you did not have all the facts before you. It is perhaps my fault that you did not have these facts; I did not give you our side of the case because I believed that to be unnecessary after Mr. Indian Agent had examined both sides of the controversy and had sent in a request that the boy be transferred from the Anousant School to the Christie School.

As will appear from the enclosed excerpts from our Baptismal and Marriage Registers, the boy's parents, Mr. and Mrs. George Martin, were both baptized as children, according to the rites of the Catholic Church, and were married in that Church. They grew up in that church and had their older children baptized in it; they are now both practical Catholics and, as will appear from their letter, which I shall quote, wish their children to be brought up in the Catholic religion and to attend a Catholic School. Some years ago, however, they sent some of their older children to the Anousant School and, I presume, duly declared that they were what they were not—Protestants. When questioned why they, being Catholics, had sent their children to a Protestant School, they replied that, at that time, they were very poor and they could not afford to send their children to the Christie School because that School made the parents pay for the pupils' clothing whereas the Anousant School gave the clothing free of charge. Whatever the reason was, they sent their older children to the Anousant School but, after leaving that place, two of them (Simon and Robert) joined the Catholic Church.

Early this last fall, two women came and told the Principal of the Christie School that Mrs. Martin would like to have him visit her as she and her husband wished to have Bob transferred. The Principal did not go. Then, the father came and was told that, if he wished to have the boy transferred, he should give his reasons in writing either to the Indian Agent or to me. I very strongly advised me not to do anything to induce or to encourage the parents to send their son to the Christie School. Some time later, the father brought a letter which I quote in full: "Indian Reserve, Optsamit, Oct 14th, 1938. Rev. Father Forbes, Christie School. Dear Father: We have had another letter from Mr. Caldwell, Principal Anousant School, asking that we send (sic) our boy Robert back to Anousant. I have written a letter to Mr. Ashbridge telling him about Robert and also asking him to put things right with Mr. Caldwell and that I was sending my boy to Christie School. I told him that we want our boy to be a Catholic like we are. I want you to please help us with the matter. I won't have my boy sent to the Anousant School. Yours truly, Mr. and Mrs. Geo. Martin."

The Principal sent the application form and, I believe, a copy of this letter to the Indian Agent. Mr. Caldwell telephoned to the Principal and letters were exchanged—all of them, I understand, out-of-town.

The Principal of the Christie School did not want the boy here until the Indian Department had approved of his admission and understood the father to say that he would keep him until after Christmas. Then, towards the end of November, the boy arrived, unannounced on the steamer, as his parents were far away, at Barclay Sound, and as he did not want to impose the boy on other Indians, the Principal agreed to keep the boy as a guest until the Department had given a ruling. For several weeks, the boy wore his own clothing and was given only a pair of rubber boots as his own were in bad shape. He was kept as a guest because we could not turn him out.

I fully realize how the Principal of the Anousant School feels after having given
Christie Indian Residential School
Kakawis, B.C.

This boy has education but there are other things to consider. The number of years the boy spent at the Ahousaht School does not right the wrong done in accepting him. I presume that the father declared himself to be a Protestant when he asked to have his son admitted but my Principal knows the value of Indians' assertions in similar circumstances and should assure himself that these declarations are truthful. In the present case this could easily have been done.

The parents were greatly to blame but they should not now be penalized for wishing to correct their original error. The boy is not needed at home as even his older brother was without work during part of the fall fishing. There are three small children, one of them an infant, at home and the parents are not well-off.

It has been stated that the boy is tubercular. The Principal here heard of that and had the boy examined with this result: "Has this child active tuberculosis in your opinion?"

Nov. 26/38
Mr. John Robertson, M.D." I might add that, since Bob's arrival here, he has gained weight and looks much better.

When this case was discussed some time ago, a friend suggested that, to avoid trouble and unpleasantness, we be satisfied to have this boy go home and, therefore, attend neither school. That would be, besides an injustice to the boy and, in the circumstances, to his parents weakly to compromise.

There is a principle at stake and it is on account of this principle that I am writing frankly but, in sincerity at least, not discourteously. Neither the Principal here nor myself wish to start a fight with any other school but we do want the children of Catholic parents here. If I had wished to start a fight or to cause you annoyance, I believe that I could, on much firmer grounds, than Mr. Caldwell has in this case, have protested the presence of certain children in the Ahousaht school. I am not, for the present, protesting but am suggesting an instance. Our registers show that the father and the mother and also their child (at about the age of one) were baptized in the Catholic church. The parents are not legally married and therefore, according to a ruling transmitted to this school by a former Indian Agent, the mother should have the custody of the child. She wants her children to be Catholics and wrote a letter asking my predecessor to baptize her latest child. We and I want to baptize the child but we could not do so because the child's father (a baptized Catholic) had promised Mr. Caldwell to let the latter baptize the child. To return to the first child mentioned, that child is in the Ahousaht school.

I mention the above facts to show that we are not going out of our way to cause trouble but, when people like the Martins come to us entirely of their own free will and ask us to take their children into school, I do not see that we have the right to refuse them. I respectfully submit that we should not always be on the losing side. To revert to the case mentioned in the preceding paragraph, I might mention that the father and another man visited the Principal here and, without being spoken to, the father said: "My child should be here but the Department decided that it should go to the Ahousaht school." He would likely say the opposite if he were talking to Mr. Caldwell but, anyway, we lost out in that case although our records show that the child and its parents are baptized Catholics.

I trust that I have not been lacking in courtesy but I wished to be frank and to give my side of the case. I request that you reconsider your decision, in view of the facts given, and that you approve of Robert Martin's transfer from a Protestant School to a Catholic School.

Yours very truly,

(P.S.) H.J. Sorensen, M.A.,

Reverend and Dear Father:

The following are the reasons why Chief Edward Joseph of this tribe (Clayoquot) wishes to put his young daughter Marjory (or Margaret) into school although she will not have attained the full age acquired for admittance into school until next fall. At present the Chief and his wife are living in a rather small house which is somewhat crowded. They have four children at home, two little girls younger than Marjory, a boy a few years older who is out of school as being T.B. suspect, and an older son who has been discharged from school. There is also a young lad, an orphan, from Kyuquot, who was discharged from school about a year ago, living with them. I understand from the Doctor that this boy has T.B. of the lungs as well as the wife of Chief Edward. Besides this unhealthful atmosphere of the home the reason given me by the mother was that she had to many little ones to take care of them properly and at the same time keep house for the rest of the family. Under these conditions I believe they have good reason to ask for their child to be admitted into school.

Sincerely,

(Rv.) H.J. Foreman O.M.I.

Reverend Sir:

A review of the December quarter return of the Christie Indian Residential School shows that pupil No. 188, Francis Charlie, is over the age of 16.

No application for retaining this boy in your school appears to have been received and in this connection I wish to direct your attention to circular letter of July 21, 1939, a copy of which is enclosed.

As pointed out in the circular letter the Department realizes that frequently there are reasons for keeping certain children after they reach the age of 16 but at the same time the consent of the Superintendent General (Minister) must be obtained.

I may add that in the past the Department has been favourably disposed to allowing certain pupils, especially girls, to remain in residential schools after they reach the age of 16 if good reasons for such action are given by the Principal and approved by the Indian Agent. However, in view of the fact that the number of children of school age is apparently increasing and the further consideration that due to the conditions now confronting us there is no immediate prospect of our securing funds to provide increased pupilage at Indian residential schools, it is considered that in future it will be necessary to adhere more strictly to the provision of the Indian Act requiring discharge of pupils at 16 years of age.

Rev. Geo. Forbes, O.M.I.,
Principal,

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Your letter dated Feb. 23rd and referring to Francis Charlie's being still in school in spite of his being 16, came yesterday afternoon. After speaking to the Indian Agent and to Mr. Inspector Barry immediately after his inspection, and with the hearty approval of the latter, I gave very good reasons to the Indian Agent for Frank's remaining here another year and asked that he be permitted to spend another year here. In a letter dated May 2nd, Mr. Indian Agent Ashbridge wrote: "I am directed to inform you that the Department approves of the under-mentioned pupils remaining in Christie Residential School for another year; #168, Frank Charlie,...". It was in the best interests of the Department as well as of the boy that I made the request; he has now a fair chance of being a self-respecting young man instead of being what he was. My predecessor very strongly urged that this boy be discharged or expelled. The boy asked me for another chance and he got it. Father Turner assures me that he is not the same boy that he was. This may be enlightening; he is the only pupil whom I have whipped this year and I did so only because he insisted that I whip him.

To keep the girls from the canneries as well as the young children whose parents greatly neglect them while working in the canneries, I am again asking that the holidays be from April 13th to June 13th. This is the only time that some parents are at home.

With kind personal regards,

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Yesterday I sent you a letter and copies of documents by ordinary mail. These deal chiefly with applications for admission to this school of certain Ahousaht children some of whom were in the Ahousaht school although I believe that they should not have been there owing to the fact that they or their parents are Catholics. Since I wrote, Simon Joseph has asked me to accept his two children one of whom was in the Ahousaht school. He (the father) was baptized in the Catholic Church (Opitsaht Register, page 27). You will recall that there was a fight about Rhoda Webster and that it was decided that she attend the Ahousaht and not the Christie School. The father (baptized in the Catholic Church, School Register page 9) brought the girl here last night and asked to have her admitted to this school. She was baptized as an infant (I point this out to show that she was not baptized while the discussion about her was going on) in the Catholic Church (School Register, page 22). The mother was also baptized in the Catholic Church (Opitsaht Register, page 20).

I have done nothing to induce these people to apply for the admission of any of these children to this school. Would you kindly tell me what to do? For certain material advantages (to have their children in a nearby school, for instance) these people may have declared that they were not Catholics but when I have records to show that they are Catholics and when, of their own accord, they ask me to accept their children, may I do so?

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6441, file 879-10, part 5)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
Christie Indian Residential School
Kakawis, B.C.
(West Vancouver Island)

So far, I have not admitted any and do not intend to do so until I have word from you. It is possible that Bishop Cody may call on the Indian Department in connection with this matter. I do not know whether he will or not but I heard that he had gone East and I know that he is interested in this matter.

I do not think that the Ahousaht day school will solve the problem. In the first place, some of these people belong to Keltsmaht, a reserve which is just a short distance from our School—a twenty minute run from here, and these people spend the summer months at this reserve but move to Ahousaht for the winter. In summer and in winter these people as well as the Ahousaht people are away from their villages fishing and doing other work so that they cannot look after children attending a day school. It has been suggested that such children, that is those whose parents do not remain at home, could be sent to the Alberni School. But that school has no right to accept Catholic children any more than I have to admit Protestant children.

As I have said, neither the missionaries nor I have invited this trouble. It has naturally arisen and we must face it. I need not add that we shall never try to "convert" Protestants just to be able to get their children to this school.

I worked right up until boat time last night and had not the time to write a long letter to you. That is why I enclosed my copy of a letter to the Indian Agent and asked that, if possible, you would kindly return the letter and the copy of documents attached.

With kind personal regards,

Yours truly,

June 26th, 1940

Dear Mr Phelan:

I am enclosing copies of letters which I am sending to the Indian Agent so that, when the cases come up, you will know on what grounds I stand. If possible, I would like to have these copies returned at your convenience. I was confidentially told by a certain official to fight cases like these. To avoid unpleasantness some might try to dodge the issue by ordering these children to the Ahousaht day school. The parents want to send the children here but I do not want to accept them until I have an official ruling from the Department. In the past, the Ahousaht School appears to have convinced the Department that Catholic children were not Catholic children. I, therefore, enclose copies of our baptismal records.

Would you kindly get me a ruling on these cases? As I said to the Indian Agent (who has always shown himself fair), it is not a question of a few more children coming to this school. It is a question of principle: Ahousaht must be shown that Catholic children must be admitted to a Catholic school. I happen to know of other cases but I do not intend to bother the Department with them until they are officially brought to my notice.

While I must keep the Bishop in touch with developments, I do not want to use this angle as any kind of disguised threat. I have to let him know whether or not Catholic children are or are not in a Catholic School.

I sincerely regret that I must give the Department this trouble.

With kind personal regards,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

AIR MAIL

Ottawa, August 29, 1940.

Dear Father Forbes:

Your letter of the 26th instant, addressed to Mr. Phelan, has been passed on to me for consideration and reply. Mr. Phelan is at this date absent from the office on holidays and is not likely to return until September 3rd.

This morning the officials have undertaken a complete search of the records relating to the enrolment of pupils at the Ahousaht Residential School. There is nothing on file here to indicate that the Paul children, sons of Samuel Paul, were ever at any time legally or illegally enrolled at the Ahousaht Residential School. The only Indian pupil named Paul that has been enrolled at that school at any time in recent years was a girl named Hazel Paul, the daughter of Matthew Arnold Paul. This particular pupil was medically examined at the time of her entrance by Dr. J. C. Robertson.

I shall be glad to discuss the claims of the Paul children for admission to the Christie Residential School with Mr. Phelan immediately following his return to the office. I regret, however, that in view of a number of epidemics that have recently broken out at residential schools in other sections of the Dominion, I cannot seriously consider the admission and enrolment of the -

Reverend George Forbes, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Christie Indian Residential School,
Kakawis, B.C.
of the Paul children until they are medically examined. Indian parents are reasonably familiar with the regulations governing the admission of pupils to our schools and it is in my judgment somewhat regrettable that they do not seek to cooperate more effectively with our Principals and thus avoid a great deal of delay and inconvenience in the enrolment of their pupils.

Yours very truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare and Training.

Dear Mr. Piellin:

The boat is coming and I am racing against time. Thank you for your letter which came on Aug. 23rd. That letter sets the Dept.'s seal of approval (as well as Bishop Cody's) on my policy. Admit no disputed cases without the Dept.'s approval.

Kindly wire collect decision on this case. Sam Paul (Catholic, Kakawis Baptismal Reg., page 12), his wife (Catholic, Opitsaht Register, page 3) wish to have their three sons transferred from Opitsaht Ras. School to this School. Two older boys are Catholics (Kakawis Bapt. Reg., page 44) and youngest has, according to father's statement, never been baptized by anyone. Father took boys to Dr. Cantor for medical examination but, according to father, the Dr. would not examine them without a note from me. The father could not take my note to the Doctor as he called at 5 p.m. and had to be back at his job as night watchman that night. He lives far from here and will not be able to come before Sept. 1st. By that time, there will be no Doctor here. He will not want to take his boys back and as I do not want to admit them, father has signed application forms and I am sending them to the Indian Agent but without the Dr.'s examination. If they were fit to be illegally admitted to Shousaht, they should still be medically fit........"Illegally"? I once asked an official of the Department why Catholic children were admitted to a certain non-Catholic School. His reply was that the R.C. missionaries had been asleep. That was unofficial but it was a fact. If I am wrong, wire me. What I intend to do is this: Try to have the father take the boys back until I hear from you (which he won't do); accept the boys only as guests.

You diplomatically evaded a question; again I ask, how far is the Department prepared to go in backing me up? Should anyone threaten Catholic parents who wish to send their children here?

Yours very truly,

Dear Mr. Hesey:

Thank you for your letter of August 29th which has just come. The officials, whom you mentioned, did not find the name of Paul Sam's children on the Ahousaht School register because the children on the West Coast take their father's second name and not his first as their family name. In the Cariboo, Johnnie Jim's children would be Frank Johnnie, Mary Johnnie, etc. Here, they would be Frank Jim, etc. The father's name is Paul Sam (and not Samuel Paul, as in your letter) and his children are Sidney Sam, Stanley Sam and Dixon Sam.

In letters to the Indian Agent, I have pointed out that I do not blame the Ahousaht authorities for accepting Catholic children. In order to keep their children near them, Catholic parents appear to have declared that they were not Catholic and their word was taken for this. Some non-Catholics would prefer to send their children here rather than to far-away Alberni and would be quite willing, unless I am mistaken, to declare that they are Catholics. In all these cases, I check up on the parents' statements before sending in an application form. Our Baptismal Registers show who is and who is not a Catholic. Thus, I find that Paul Sam, his woman (not wife) and the two older boys are Catholics. The youngest is not a Catholic. The father declares that the boy is not baptized.

The Indians and we are greatly inconvenienced by there being no Doctor in the vicinity. New-comers cannot be examined.

Yours very truly,

G. Johnson

It will be noted that Lena Titian, Bessie Joseph and Rose Joseph were pupils at the Ahousaht school, and I quote from the letter of the Rev. Principal explanation as to the reason for these applications:

"Bessie and Rose Joseph. Their father declares that he is a Catholic and the reference given me in Opitsaht Baptismal Register, page 27, I have looked this up and have found: Simon(sic), born at Keltsomah, in Sept.1907, son of Jimmie and Katie, baptized on Feb.28th,1915 by Father Joseph Schindler. Sponsors, Billie Joseph and Annie. I cannot recall which of the missionaries informed me that this is Simon Joseph. The Keltsomah children tell me that Simon's mother was Katie but they do not know his father's name.

Lena Titian—I have no reason to believe that her mother, who is dead, was a Catholic but her step-mother (Tommy Marshall's daughter, Josephine) is a Catholic, as you know, and so is her father. His baptism by Father Tunner is recorded on page 54 of the Opitsaht Register (Baptismal). (That refers to Joe Titian). However, I know that Joe Titian was married by a Catholic Priest, Father Bourne, in 1932 prior to his baptism by Father Tunner. That indicates that either his former wife or Joe Titian was a Catholic in 1935. If his wife was not a Catholic, he was."

I feel that the Department should be advised that since the loss of the Residential school at Ahousaht, most of the Indians living at Ahousaht have discovered that they are Catholics. This is borne out in a number of cases by the baptismal register and the history of the Coast shows that the Catholic Church originally established all the missions on the Coast. With the institution of a Protestant School at Ahousaht much later it can only be presumed that the Indians found it convenient to send their children to Ahousaht School, and made false statements as to their religion.

Dear Sir:

Received your letter and application forms and stating that my wife with her father were there wishing to send Rhoda and Basil to that school. Yes, they had the right to call on you because I have been talking about sending my children there but I don't even get a chance to get in touch with you. Always on fishing grounds.

My children won't get no education if they attend to day-school because I'm away from home most of the time. Can't always stay home just to have my children attending day-school. So I want them to get well educated because I know how it is when you haven't much education it doesn't matter much to me about religion because you two churches are praying to the same God. We got Rhoda to Ahousaht School because Mr Caldwell thought we Indians were just like White people. Did not want to see my children separated to each other that's Rhoda being in Christie School and Basil in Ahousaht School.

We Indians always get back together even whatever we each one are. Rhoda and Basil would have been sister and brother just the same if Rhoda stayed in Christie School.

I know there'll be quite a time before this is settled. I sure will see you when I come down home. I'll be home on 14th of February from Vancouver.

Of course I'm to sign the forms you send up very kind of you to do that. See you later and good bye. Yours Peter Webster.
