Dear Sir:

Thank you for your recent letter and also for the paint, lumber, etc., which came on the 23rd. In reply to your question, I beg to state that the wood which the Department found so expensive was for use in the manual training shop. We can very easily do without it.

A few days ago, Mrs. Peter Webster called and stated that she and Peter wished to have their children, Rhoda and Basil, admitted to this school. I pointed out that I could not accept these pupils not only because they had attended the Ahousaht School but because, I have been told, the father made an affidavit to the effect that he is or was a Protestant. However, I agreed to write to the father, to send him application forms and again to submit the case to Ottawa.

Enclosed, please find excerpts from our Baptismal Register. These show that Peter Webster, Jessie Tom, and their child, Rhoda, were all baptized as Catholics. There is no record of Basil's baptism. He was almost certainly baptized as a member of the United Church. The Ahousaht records will show whether my assumption is right or wrong.

The mother, Jessie Tom, is and has always been a Catholic. The father, Peter, was baptized as a Catholic but I am told that he attended the Ahousaht School. Moreover, when his daughter's case was studied, two or three years ago, I am told that he made an affidavit stating that he was a Protestant. What are the facts and what is the value of that affidavit is what we have to find out. In my letter to Peter (of which I gave you a copy), I asked him to tell me whether he had become a Protestant. He did not reply to this question. I asked him why, since he, his wife and daughter had been baptized as Catholics, he had let the daughter attend the Ahousaht School. At first sight, his answer seems untruthful; Basil was too young to be in school at the time. His meaning, however, seems to be that he did not want his children in different schools and that Mr. Caldwell, who has named, evidently told him that Basil, being a Protestant, would attend the Ahousaht School. He was quite truthful when he wrote: "It doesn't matter much to me about religion." While I am certain that Mr. Caldwell felt that Peter was telling the truth when he made the affidavit, it seems to me that the man's religious affiliations are motivated by his desire to have his children educated. He was baptized as a Catholic and, for all I know, he may have been baptized again as a member of the United Church. Naturally, if he was baptized a second time, no mention of the first baptism would likely have been made. Then, again, if he were a Protestant, why did he have his daughter come here in the first place before she was transferred to Ahousaht? This letter seems to indicate that he allowed steps to be taken or took steps to have Rhoda transferred to the Ahousaht School so that, when her brother was of age to go to school, they would be in the same school. From Peter's letter, it seems to look as if Mr. Caldwell suggested the idea. If he did, I can find nothing wrong in his action. Was not Peter brought up at Ahousaht school? Did he not (I presume he did) attend Protestant services? Did he say anything to let Mr. Caldwell even suspect that he had even been baptized? Had he not had or at least promised to have a younger child baptized by Mr. Caldwell? If he took any, seems to me to have been without blame. Moreover, before he transferred from here to Ahousaht, Mr. Caldwell prudently insisted on getting an affidavit stating that Peter was a Protestant. What was the value of such an affidavit? He may sincerely have become a Protestant. It seems to me that his motives may have been education of his children... About two years ago, Peter called here to see his friend (one of our pupils) and, out of a blue sky, remarked that Rhoda should be here also. The Government had decided otherwise. Would you please submit the case to Ottawa and know how they will decide it. The Department does not wish to see families divided. However, Rhoda is a Catholic and should be here. On the other hand, I fully believe that Basil is not a Catholic and should not be here... unless it can honestly be shown that the father is a Catholic and that the children's religion is judged by himself from...
ion is that although baptized as a Catholic, he was brought up as a Protestant, and that he is not interested in religion but only in the education of his children. Shortly before I came here, he appears to have given a very clear sign that he wished to act as a Catholic. A little later, he gave quite as clear a sign to the contrary... His wife asked Father Leo (the letter is still here) to baptize a younger child. Father Leo went to Monsignor Caldwell to let him do the baptizing.

There are further details but you know them. What I have said, I have tried to say fairly.

My policy has been not to admit a disputed case until the Department had approved of the admission of the child to this school. A few days ago, I broke this rule. Martin Charlie, about to go fishing, sent his son here with an uncle. At the time, as well as just before and after it, the sea was very rough and the boy's clothes were soaking. Rather than send the boy back and risk another soaking, I let him stay but pointed out to the uncle that I would keep the boy only as a guest until word came from Ottawa. An application form for his admission had already been sent in for Ottawa's consideration. That I did well in keeping him seems to be proved, that the Doctor and two men capsized twice in attempts to reach our motor launch. A traveller and I got off with one sick bath. The Webster children are not here and will not be admitted unless the Dept approves of their admission.

I am pleased to be able to state that all are well.

Yours very truly,

G. Forbes, O.M.I.

Rhoda Webster was admitted to Ahousaht Residential School on November 28th, 1938 - your file 159-2-10, November 28, 1938; and Basil Webster was admitted to the same school January 26th, 1940, file 159-2-10, January 26, 1940.

Rhoda's admission to Ahousaht was approved after much correspondence re the parents' religion, and since the destruction of the Ahousaht School the father contends that both he and his wife are Catholics, and he now seeks admission for his children to Christie School.

Ottawa,
May 17, 1945.

Mr. F.B. Ashbridge, Indian Agent, Port Alberni, B.C.

With reference to your letter of the 11th instant, the Department approves the admission of Wilson George to the Christie Residential School, provided he is pronounced physically fit by the Medical Officer.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

I am forwarding the attached application form on behalf of Wilson George, Clayoquot Band, age 8, and beg to advise that this boy's father died a few days ago leaving the boy an orphan, and with no one to sign for him as guardian.

I would respectfully recommend that this application be granted and steps will be taken to provide him with a guardian before leaving school. He has not been medically examined due to the absence of Doctors, and this will be carried out as soon as a Doctor is available.

P. B. Ashbridge,
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, 27th August, 1945.

Mr. R.H. Moore, Indian Agent, Duncan, B.C.,

I have your letter of the 24th instant with reference to two sons of Tommy George.

While I agree with you that the parents should accept their responsibility in training their children properly, at the same time if they do not do so I feel there is no reason why we should allow the children to suffer. If these boys should remain at home and continue to act as mentioned in the third para of your letter, it is possible that their actions may become more serious.

Taking everything into consideration, I feel that they should be placed in the Christie Residential School provided they are physically fit.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

I have had a request from Tommy George of the Songhees Band to allow his two sons of 10 and 12 years old to attend the Christie Residential School in the West Coast Agency, and to which the Principal of the School has agreed if the approval of the Dept. can be obtained.

In this connection I may say that one of the Priests connected with Indian Missionary work in the Agency and on the Songhees Reserve in particular discussed the matter with me today. I explained to him that the policy of the Dept. was to encourage Indian children to attend the schools on their reserve providing they were of the same religious denomination and the parents of the children were able to support them and that the home conditions were also satisfactory. In this particular case, home conditions are satisfactory, the parents can give the necessary home care and support, but are weak in discipline the result being that their two sons are doing much as they please around their home reserve and will eventually get into trouble.

Previously, these lads attended the Songhees Indian Day School but were not particular regular in their attendance, playing hockey on many occasions, which after all could not be laid at the door of their parents. The whole setup as I see it is this: "Does the Department wish to allow the parents of these children to shirk their responsibilities as parents with respect to the discipline and support of their two boys, or do you feel that in the interests of the boys themselves we might be doing more good by allowing them to go to the Residential school?" I hardly know just what to recommend in this case as I feel that there is no good and sufficient reason why the boys should not go to their reserve day school, other than the fact that their parents are not strict enough with them and they may eventually get into a lot of trouble. Please advise.

With reference to the attached applications for admission to the Christie Residential School of the above named children, I wish to report that the father is not a Catholic, but the mother was, and this man expressed the desire that he wished these children to attend a Catholic school and be instructed in that religion.

I discussed this matter with the Rev. J. P. Mulvihill, Principal of Christie School, and was advised that he would be willing to receive these children under the above conditions if that would be agreeable to the Department.

I would recommend that these children be admitted to Christie School, as their home reserve is almost entirely Catholic.

1. On this date the undersigned letter was forwarded to this Detachment by Mr. H.M. Taylor, Indian Agent, for Vancouver Survey, which is self explanatory.

DEPUTY

Dear Mr. Taylor,

I received a letter from the Principal of the Christie Residential School advising that a Mary Lucas, the mother of one of his pupils "Henry Jones" (14) intended to keep him out of school and that this would be unfortunate as she is not a proper guardian for him as she was probably living with her own parents and family before.

I have written to Mary Lucas instructing her to return the boy to school and that the only exception I could make to his not returning was that of sickness or other unavoidable cause.

The reply I received is to the effect that she was not well and that the boy was required to do the work around the house.

I believe you have the services of a Constable in your district who if he could sometime, when he is in that neighbourhood, make a few inquiries regarding this case, I would be obliged as I am of the opinion that this is an excuse to get him working.

Mary Lucas's Address is: St. Jameson Cannery Nelson Bros., Fishermen, New Westminster, B.C.

Sgd. H.M. Taylor

2. Whilst on patrol at the above named place the writer interviewed the file subject this same date. Her excuse to the writer was that, in view of the fact that she is pregnant she has been ill and needed the boy to help her. However, a check in the Cannery Time Office disproved the story that she had been ill because no time had been lost since she had been employed there. She was in good health. She informed the writer that she did not expect the baby until sometime in December.

3. In view of the foregoing a written order was served on the file subject to cause the attendance at school of her son "Henry Jones". At the time this order was served Mary informed the writer that she would have to wait till payday before she could take the boy away, so she was advised to contact Mr. Taylor, Indian Agent, at Vancouver, B.C.

4. On this date a patrol was made to the Cannery by the writer where it was ascertained that the file subject...
...Cont'd. - had removed the boy on the 5th of October and had returned to the Cariboo on the 15th instant by himself. The boy presumably having been sent to school. Unfortunately at the time of the writer's visit the file subject was not available for interview.

5. There is no suggestion at this point of the file subject living with any other person.

CONCLUDED NO EXPENSE

Ottawa, July 5th, 1947.

Dear Father Mulvihill:

With reference to your letter of the 25th ultimo, the school calendar published in the recent issue of our Bulletin applied only to Indian day schools.

As regards residential schools, the regulation in effect for many years and which still applies, provides that the Department will allow a grant for 62 days holidays each year. In the past residential schools have closed on July 1st and reopened on September 1st, which is, of course, exactly 62 days.

In certain districts, owing to local conditions we know that some schools close two or three days earlier or even may be delayed a day or so after September 1st and we do not make any cut in the grant. However, generally speaking we expect all residential schools to observe the regulations, namely 62 days holidays with grant.

I cannot understand why Alberni School should close as early as stated in your letter and I am communicating with the principal in this regard.

In preparing the September return the number of days in the quarter should be shown as 92 and grant should be requested for each pupil for the actual number of days such pupil is in residence during the September quarter, plus 62 days holiday grant.

We have not made any definite ruling yet in connection with allowing children to go home from
residential schools at Christmas. There has been considerable agitation on the part of some Indians to have this privilege allowed and it is a question that has been before the Department on very many occasions during the past twenty years.

We have always felt that in the majority of cases at least, we would simply be looking for trouble if we allowed the children home for Christmas. It might be alright in the case of children whose home reserve is very close to the residential school. However, if the children have to travel in the winter time a considerable distance, there is always the danger of them developing some illness as a result of changed conditions on the reserve from those in the residential school. Inevitably there would also be delays in returning in many cases, possibly due to climatic conditions over which none of us have any control.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.

Rev. J.P. Mulvihill, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Christie Indian Res. School,
Kakawis, B.C.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

I am enclosing the September Quarterly hoping it is completed to your satisfaction. I am sorry that I failed to complete it as called for. I feel I shall be able to do it rightly the next time without much trouble. As it is I was principal for only one month and had only a few days instructions on the whole matter of the duties of the Principal before the former Principal Father Mulvihill left for his new post. In a way I am glad you sent the return back to me in order that I could really see my mistakes. I am as anxious to do it well as you are to have it done.

Hoping that everything is to the satisfaction of both of us,

1. August Family - This family is in the West Coast Agency in the Province of British Columbia. The father is deceased and the mother is responsible for the children. James age 8 and John age 8 were admitted to the Alberni Indian residential school (U.C.) in 1950. The applications at that time indicated that the family was United Church and were signed by the mother Ida August and were recommended for admission by the Indian Superintendent.

We have now received applications signed by Mrs. Ida August asking that they be transferred from the Alberni (U.C.) residential school to the Christie (R.C.) residential school. The Indian Superintendent recommends this transfer.

Indian Superintendent should ascertain the religion of the widow mother. If she is U.C., children to attend Protestant school. If R.C., children to attend R.C. school. (Sgd) L.F.

The request for the admission of the above-mentioned children to the Christie (R.C.) Indian Residential School has been received and carefully considered.

The following ruling has been made:

"Indian Superintendent should ascertain the religion of the widowed mother. If she is United Church, children should attend Protestant school. If Roman Catholic, children to attend Roman Catholic school".

In your letter of March 3rd you stated that the religious denomination of Mrs. August mother of John and James August is Roman Catholic. In view of the above ruling, the Department approves the admission of these children to the Christie Indian Residential School.

On the March Quarterly Return, the Principal should request grant from the date the boys were admitted to the school.

Sir:

With the consent of Mr. E. E. Frost, Indian Agent of this Agency, on visit to the Christie Indian Residential School at my special request, I am enclosing this letter with his memorandum to you of his findings here. I have asked his leave to do this in order that you may have my explanation of requests which may perhaps be unusual. I am hoping that you will favor me with a direct reply; through Mr. Frost, if you wish, that through this direct contact I, a new Principal, may be helped to understand and appreciate your attitude toward matters of this nature.

There are three items which Mr. Frost and I discussed at length concerning which I am anxious for you to have my view. These three items are: (1) sewing machines, (2) carpenter tools, and (3) tools and gasoline engine.

You will agree with me, I am sure, that besides instruction in English, arithmetic, etc., the Indian should be instructed in that which will prove of practical use to him after he leaves school. For the female Indian there should be instruction in sewing. Sister Superior and the Sister in charge of that class at Christie School and I have gone over the subject thoroughly. What we would like to have the Department help us do is to make it possible to have every girl attending Christie School attend a class in sewing when she reaches a certain age. Ordinarily there would be about fifteen individuals in such a class at one time. That means to conduct the class with satisfactory results the Sister should have available eleven sewing machines. She informs me that these eleven machines would be in use during practically all and every class; in other words, that the number of machines we say we need is not overestimated. At present there are six sewing machines in the school. Of these four are fit for use and two are not. We would, therefore, respectfully ask of the Department seven new sewing machines to complete the number of eleven we need to conduct this class in sewing satisfactorily.

As to the question of carpenter tools: the male Indian has ample need of an elementary knowledge of carpentry. I do not think the subject requires any amplification. My suggestion is that the only thing needed would be to have a class in carpentry in a carpenter shop for the purpose. The more expensive and heavier tools would be the property of the school and placed at the disposal of the student during class hours. The smaller tools, saw, hammer, etc., would be supplied in sets to each student, be placed in a box to be taken home by him when he receives his discharge, and returned to the school be kept in an individual locker or cabinet in the carpentry shop for him for class duty. It appears to me this feature would be of great benefit to the student and would militate against loss or abuse of the tools. In connection with this matter, will the Department negotiate further with me regarding the following: (1) the equipment of the School with the tools necessary for conducting classes in sewing and carpentry; (2) the supply of the material such as lumber, nails, etc., required for the use of each student; (3) a grant or allowance for the instructor.

of the West Coast Indian agree unanimously that he will not do anything but fish for a livelihood. Conversation with Indian boys attending Christie School has revealed to me that the ambition of practically every boy is to own a fishing launch as do his elders after he receives his discharge. This fact suggests the desirability of the Indian having a thorough knowledge of a gasoline engine and some knowledge of electricity. I propose dealing with this phase of the Indians' education in this manner; a class in these two subjects. May I, for the benefit of those to whom this perhaps unusual letter is addressed, explain, that, having been appointed to the position of Principal of the Christie Indian Residential School with the understanding that the appointment is to be permanent, I purpose to work for the welfare of the Indians in my charge with all the talent I possess and with all the zeal, earnestness and determination I can command. I bring to my task an experience of practically sixteen years in the education of youth, during which time I served as professor, disciplinarian and college-president. The problems I meet in my new field of endeavor I hope to solve satisfactorily, with the information I have acquired during that time, ably assisted by the advice and guidance of the capable gentlemen under whose supervision it is my good fortune to find myself. It is my purpose to bend every effort to realize the objectives the Department wishes the School to realize and to do so by a conscientious observance of the laws and regulations the Department has laid down for my guidance.

I am at pains to express myself in this manner because I would instil in the members of the Department the hope that whatever shortcomings may have been in evidence in the past management of Christie School, better things are in prospect.

Very truly and respectfully yours,

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of letter of the Deputy Minister dated the 23rd ultimo asking me to see what could be done in the way of purchasing a launch for the use of the Christie School, at Clayoquot, West Coast Agency, and that the meditated expenditure in this connection would be approximately $3,500.00 for a boat 35 or 37 ft. long.

In reply I beg to say that on the 26th ultimo Reverend Father Victor, the Principal of the School, called at this office on his return from Ottawa, and the matter of acquiring a launch was discussed. I informed him, as I am informing you, that I am strongly of the opinion that it would not be possible to obtain a launch 35 or 37 ft. long, suitable for the West Coast waters, for the sum of $3,500.00.

I have learned, however, that there is in Victoria Harbour at the present time a fishing vessel No. 557 GA seized by the Fishery Department some little time ago which, I believe, with some alteration, would answer our purpose. The dimensions of this vessel are length 36' over all, beam 11'5" draft 3'6", and it has an "Enterprise" gasoline engine of 15--17 horsepower. This vessel is now in the hands of the sheriff and will be sold unless it is expropriated by the Government for public purposes as provided for under Section 17 of the "Customs and Fisheries Protection Act" being Chapter 43 Revised Statutes, 1927, a typewritten copy of the Section being hereto attached.

I spoke to the Reverend Principal of the School with regard to this boat, but he thought possibly he might be able to get one built in the vicinity of Clayoquot for the $3,500.00 provided by the Department and, if not, he was prepared to put in a small sum himself.

I still have my doubts as to whether any decent sea-going boat could be purchased for anywhere near the sum mentioned, but we could have this boat (No. 557 GA) expropriated for public use. Any alterations necessary should be done for considerably less than the $3,500.00. There, of course, will be certain fees to be paid if the boat is taken over, as the sheriff has now a watchman on board and the expenditure in this connection already amounts to something over $300.00.

Dear Sir:

The matter has gone over very carefully by the Indian agent, Mr. Frost and myself with the Sister in charge of our sewing department, and we cut down our needs to the very limit of what was deemed necessary to carry on the class efficiently and without disorganizing seriously the girls' department - so easily done because of the unsatisfactory conditions here and over which we have no control.

Furthermore, in taking over this position, I am most desirous to train our boys and girls well in the work they will be called upon to do after leaving school; and I can't conceive, after the encouraging tone of your letter as regards training of boys in their subjects, the Department handicapping me in my efforts for the girls for the sake of two sewing machines, unless there be some misunderstanding.

And it is only because I feel certain that there is a misunderstanding that I am making bold to trouble the Department to rehear the situation. I am sure after this explanation it will reconsider the matter and oblige the school as per my original request.

Dear Sir:

This letter is a reply to your communication dated the 28th ult., file number 159-011, re: "manual training classes for the boys at the Christie Indian Residential School."

Mr. Commissioner Ditchburn, on my return from the East, instructed me to report to him on the matter which I did. My list of tools, however, was substituted by another, to which action of the Commissioner I was quite agreeable. Now, however, since the Department has revived the subject as pertains to me, I am taking the liberty of expressing to it certain recommendations as I received these from the instructor I have engaged.

The work we have outlined departs radically, I am told, from the usual instruction imparted in manual training classes. We have kept in mind the ultimate purpose this class is intended to serve. I will mention but one of them: the building and furnishing of a house. The instructor has in mind to lead the class along step by step in the manufacture and construction of all that is necessary for this, eventually, if possible, having each boy of the class build a miniature house. He has in mind, moreover, the erection of a house of small proportions by the entire class, the plan of which, after careful study, would be an attempt to present to the members of the class and to Indians visiting the school, the ideal Indian dwelling on the West Coast as to arrangement and construction.

Unfortunately, the tools on the list submitted by Mr. Commissioner Ditchburn are inadequate for this purpose. Not, therefore, as an expression of disapproval of his action, but to expedite matters in case the Department should wish us to proceed in the manner outlined, I am forwarding to McLennan, McFeely & Prior of Vancouver, B.C., a supplementary list with instructions to send an estimate of their cost to you direct.

Mr. Commissioner Ditchburn has furthermore instructed me to proceed with the construction of twelve work-benches for as many members of the class, the cost of which is not to exceed $12.00 a piece. I intended to call his attention to the fact that material for an instructor's bench and tool-cabinets (with locks) was thereby left out of consideration. Now, however, I shall take this opportunity to suggest to you my recommendations, namely, that the Department, with a view to assist the school to the extent implied, instruct me to submit rough plans for the space we have set aside for our student carpenter shop and an estimate of the cost of the lumber and material it would require to make the room reasonably serviceable for our purpose. The Department may reply that I should be able to buy such extras from my grant, but the truth is I find providing the extras not covered by the estimate for the present improvements is necessitating my being quite frugal with expenditures.
Finally, permit me to say that I entertain bright hopes for the success of this class. I intend to prosecute its possibilities energetically, of course, on the condition the Department so desires. I used the opportunity offered by my presence in Vancouver on returning from the East to engage an instructor for the work; the gentleman's salary being $75.00 a month and board from September 8th on. I was more or less compelled to this premature action by the nature of circumstances here at school which make it most inconvenient for me to get away. I trust that the Department understands my situation and will contribute toward the instructor's salary accordingly.

Faithfully yours,

Victor Rassier, O.S.B.

Dear Sir:

I have been having some correspondence with Reverend Father Victor, Principal of the Christie School, with regard to the establishing of manual and technical training classes in that institution, and in a recent letter he quoted an excerpt from his letter to yourself of the 5th of March last, and your reply of the 12th of April on that particular subject. The Principal supplied me with a list of carpenters' tools required for his class of twelve pupils, and also a considerable list of machinists' tools as well as a request for a gasoline engine to be used among the pupils for demonstrating purposes.

In my reply to the Principal, I pointed out that the list of carpenters' tools was not in line with the equipment that has been supplied to other schools, and it was the desire of the Department that all the schools should be uniformly equipped so far as the carpenter shops were concerned, and I furnished him with a list of what had already been supplied last year to ten of our residential schools in the Province, and this is quite agreeable to him. Reverend Father Victor apparently has hired a competent mechanic who is capable of giving instruction in the carpentry shop as well as the machine shop, and, with regard to the latter, I am herebelow quoting from his letter of the 26th ultimo for your information:

"Your letter calls for information as to the purpose of the engine and the horse-power required. The engine is to serve demonstration purposes to the class taking instruction. Among other things, the instructor intends to have the class take the engine apart, know the purposes of each part, be able to assemble the engine; he purposes to stall the engine in various ways and have the members of the class detect and remedy the trouble, etc., etc.

"For this a new engine is not absolutely necessary; in fact, a second hand one might be better for our purpose. It should, however, be complete (battery and high tension magneto), and of any type (naval or medium duty) make (Easthope, Palmer, Universal), Engle, Raylins, etc., etc., and horsepower (six to eight) used by the Indians on the West Coast on their fishing boats.

"It is possible that we might be able to secure such a second-hand engine in the immediate neighborhood. If it is your wish we would make investigations and, finding a suitable one, get the owner to submit an estimate to you."

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

So......
So far as the cost of the equipment is concerned, that for the carpentry shop is estimated to be approximately $550.00 and the engine tools about $200.00. The gasoline self-ignition Fairbanks-Morse engine costs $385.00, but it is possible a second-hand engine could be picked up in the district that would suit the purpose of the School. The total cost of this equipment, therefore, would be approximately $1,000.00, and I would be pleased to know how far you are prepared to go in this direction. The carpentry tools undoubtedly should be purchased, and if you so authorize, I will place an order for them. If the money is available, I would also recommend that the machinists' tools be purchased, and the Principal be written to to see what he can do in the way of obtaining a second-hand engine in the district for demonstrating purposes.

Reverend Father Victor, while being a new man, seems to have the proper idea of what is necessary in the way of giving the Indians of the West Coast a good practical training, and I am of the opinion that he should be encouraged by the Department in this direction so far as it is possible to do so.

Your obedient servant,

W.E. Ditchburn,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Sir:

Your letter of the 19th instant, No.101/15/15456, was duly received. I am making haste to answer in accordance with the request with which it terminated, and I beg you to consider the nature of this reply prompted by the same motives that suggested the contents of your letter, namely, a desire to advance the interests of your Department.

The launch I suggested to the Department on my visit to Ottawa is part of a program I devised and have been adhering to scrupulously in my efforts to accomplish the work I conceive it is the Department's wish I should do. Before going to Ottawa, I had for months thought over this launch and had heard from those capable of giving it. It was to the naval architect presented the fruition of these painstaking efforts, and the plans he is finishing will be for a launch such as will best contribute to the objective for which the idea of the launch was conceived in the first place.

Unfortunately, the kind of boat you describe in your letter will not adapt itself to my purpose. It is for this reason, that I beg you not to consider me as discarding the sound sense and prudent judgment which I have learned to know you to possess so abundantly, when I make bold to suggest that you empower me to proceed in the manner it is possible for me to do here.

After receiving your letter, I again went over the position with the gentleman I spoke to you about, and again he assured me that he would not charge me more than the $3,500.00 in carrying out the plans of the architect. I accept your statement that on its face this is impossible. However, when I explain that the gentleman in question, whose work is highly commended hereabouts, is an old ship-builder, is fond of the mission, has taken a liking to me, and regards the commission of making the launch with a certain amount of pride and as an opportunity to assist a most laudable undertaking, you will find it easier to understand why the sum of $3,500.00 will be quite ample. All the more so, when I add that his son is almost capable machinist and also interested in the underlying motives that actuate the father; while the owner of a mill in the neighborhood has guaranteed all the lumber that is acceptable for the launch as a means of reimbursing the Church for timber he wishes to remove from land belonging to it and which is located near his mill.

I am at pains to disclose these details at the risk of trying your patience because, on the one hand, I do not want you to think me—paradox the expression—half-hearted or inclined to oppose the wishes of capable superiors; on the other hand, I am very anxious to have the launch be in every way the asset to my labors it was originally conceived it would be. And because you are a man to whom one may trust a frank expression of opinion, I am not hesitating to declare myself in this manner. I have reason...

Mr. W.M. Pritchburn,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Victoria, B.C.
reason to know that your assistance and cooperation can be expected by those giving evidence of protecting and promoting the interests of your Department; and trusting that this letter reveals me as trying faithfully to accomplish this, I am hopeful of your favourable consideration of my request.

Very truly yours,

SPECIFICATION
for
35 foot "Y" bottom motor launch

Dimensions:
Length overall ------------------ 35' 0"
Breadth ------------------------ 9' 0"
Depth moulded to raised deck --- 6' 1½"

General:
The intention of this specification and the accompanying plans (drawing numbers 856 A, B, C, D by T. Halliday, Naval Architect of Vancouver, B.C.) is to provide for the construction and delivery in the water complete of a 35 foot "Y" bottom motor launch; the specification and plans are intended to cooperate so that any work described or shown in one and not in the other is to be carried out as though fully dealt with in both; and even if certain work is not described or shown and same be necessary and usual, the builder, knowing his business, will carry out same and will provide material and properly fasten together.

Materials:
All materials to be of best quality and all lumber to be well seasoned and free from deleterious defects.

Workmanship:
To be sound and good and in accordance with the usual practice in this class of vessel; skin to be well planed and sand papered to a smooth finish; deck edges to be planed smooth before laying the canvas.

Fastenings:
To be of the best galvanized iron throughout; the following are the principle sizes:

Fore feet and main deadwood..............¾" thro' bolts
Keel & hog.........................7/16" "
Chine beamshelf, side clamps, etc., bolts in shaft log, beamends.............3/8"
Frame connections, knee arms, butts of skin, etc..........................5/16"
Skin to frames, & deck to beams........2" boat nails
Beam shelf to be through bolted to skin on every frame.
Side clamp to have one through bolt on alternate frames and two spikes on remainder;
Chine to have one through bolt to rise knee on alternate frames and two screws on remained where the bevel is too much to allow of a bolt, frames to have two bolts on each end where connected to floors and chine knees;
Frame heels to have a 2" spike to hog;
Skin to have two nails in each frame and three in each hood end;
Skin butts to have two bolts in each plank through the oak butt straps.

Cementing:
The spaces at the heels of the frames to be filled with bituminous cement or pitch.

Painting:
The interior of the boat after planking and before fitting the ceiling to be coated with a bitumastic enamel; the under water skin to have at least two coats of "Union Jack" copper paint; hardwood to have at least three
Painting: three coats of "Valspar" or equal varnish; the remainder of the work to receive three coats of "Lagoline" in approved colors; name to be painted on each bow and name with port of registry on stern; care to be taken that all weather joints are thoroughly tight.

Caulking: Seams to be filled with at least two threads of cotton well hardened up and filled with "Kuhl's" elastic seam composition.

Stopwaters: Of hardwood to be fitted in all joints which cross the rabet.

Keel: - 22" x 7½" Fir, with 7/8" x 3¼" Gum shoe.
Hog: 22" x 6½" Fir.
Stem: 3¾" x 9½" Gum.
Sternpost: 24" x 5½" gum swelled in way if shafting as necessary.
Shaft leg: In two pieces of 22" x 4½" fir.
Deadwood: Of fir sided 3¾".
Horn timber: 4½" x 6½" fir.
Transom post: 3¾" x 6½" fir.
Frames: Lower part of oak, sides of fir 1¾"x x 2"m., spaced 1¾" o.c.
Chine: 24" x 6½" fir, well rounded, in one piece fore and aft.
Beam shelf: 1¾" x 3½" fir in one piece.
Side clamp: 1¾" x 3½" fir in one piece.
Floors: Engine floors of 2¾" fir; other floors of 1¾" x 4½" fir or as shown.
Skin: Bottom of fir and sides of cedar 1" finished thickness and out of edged grainwood; butts to be well shifted and fitted with oak buttstraps 8" long, 1" thick and ½" wider than planks; top of straps to be beveled to prevent accumulation of water.

Deck: Of 7/8" cedar "V" joint T & G and covered with #12 canvas; deck to be well painted before laying canvas and canvas to receive as many coats of paint as necessary to completely fill the pores.

Flooring: Of 2¾" fir T & G carried on floors.
Cockpit floor: Of 2¾" fir T & G and covered with #12 canvas and painted same as deck; beams of 1¾" x 2½" fir cambered 1¾"; 1¾" lead drain pipes to be fitted at after end.

Ceiling: Of 7/16" cedar "V" joint T & G.

Wheelhouse: As shown, of Philippine mahogany with four hinged sashes four sliding and four fixed; floor of 2¾" fir T & G carried on 1¾" x 2½" fir beams; a portable hatch to be arranged over the engine; a hinged door and portable hatch cover to be fitted for closing off the fore cabin; double mahogany doors to be fitted at aft end.

Cabin: To be furnished two settees having lockers under, two cupboards, dresser with sink & locker, dish rack, mahogany ladder, mahogany folding table, stove with asbestos and galv'd iron insulation, toilet on Star'd side.

Awning aft: Carried on 1" galv'd pipe stanchions, supported by 1¾" x 2" Y. Cedar beams and planked with 7/16" cedar covered with painted canvas.
Deck Beams: Of Y. cedar 2" x 2½" to 2" stronger beams at openings.

Miscellaneous: Oak foot bars on deck, oak mouldings, seats in cockpit, lamp boxes, mahogany hatch, hanging knees of 1½" vine maple, breasthooks, 1½" transom planking, cockpit coaming of mahogany, gun bitt for'd 4½ sq., fairwater pieces at aft end of stern post.

Fittings: Rudder of 2" gum with galv'd stock and quadrant. Mahogany steering wheel with brass mountings. Galv'd wire rope steering leads with turnbuckles, pulleys, etc., complete. One iron skag galv'd. One iron chain block galv'd. Four galv'd fairlead chocks. One galv'd mooring cleat. One galv'd chain pipe. One galv'd chain roller on stem. Galv'd hand rails as shown. Two 4" upcast ventilators and trunks. One 4" downcast vent'r. One stove pipe water plate with pipe and liverpool head. One 1" seminary pump, double acting, with galv'd suction pipe, with foot valve & strainer and discharge pipe. One 25g. galv'd water tank with filling pipe, air pipe, and suction pipe to pump, with brass valve on tank. One pantry pump of brass tinned inside. One sink with discharge pipe overboard. One "Shanks" underline W.C. completely piped up, and with shut off cocks at sea end. Six brass hinged port lights, 6" openings. One #7 "Mascot" or naval stove. Two 3½g. Galv'd gasoline tanks with filling pipe, air pipe, bronze valves, etc., complete. One mast head lamp pole. One flag staff with socket, lines, cleat & trunk of H.W. Hardware of bronze of substantial design. Anchors, chain, rope, navigation lamps as selected by the Rev. Victor Rassler O.S.B.

Electric Lighting: Storage battery for 72 hours; the wiring to be on the low tension 6 volt system; boat to be wired with suitable braided, insulated wiring inside and lead covered outside; inside wiring to be laid thro' beams and covered with neat moulding; navigation lamps to be connected with W.T. flush receptacle mounted on wheel house; the following lamps to be provided:

- Fore cabin..................2 10 watt lamps
- Galley........................1 "
- W.C..........................1 "
- Wheelhouse...................2 "
- Compass......................1 5 "
- Navigation lamps.............5 5 "
- Cockpit......................2 10 "

A switchboard with requisite switches, ammeter, voltmeter, automatic cut out and resistance.
Electrical Lighting: Searchlight capable of illuminating an object half a mile distant with wiring and separate switch. One "Klassen" horn with wiring and push button. Trouble lamp with flexible wiring and plug. It is understood that the above calls for a complete installation in good working order.

Engine: Make of engine and horsepower to ensure a speed of not less than eight miles an hour to be provided according to the wishes of the Rev. Victor Rassier, C.S.B.

Engine Installation: To be installed in place in complete working order, including "Hyde" three bladed propeller of 20" dia., and 17" pitch, bronze tail shaft, bronze shaft tube with after bearing and gland, copper fuel pipes, gasoline strainer and water trap, galv'd exhaust pipe, galv'd circulating water pipes, bronze Welding done bolted engine controls led to steering position bronze tail shaft and cone on propeller, back fire trap on carburettor, "Auto Vae" tank over engine, engine starting handle in Wheelhouse; the whole installation to be in complete working order.
Dear Sir:

Referring to your letter of 9th of October last dealing with the construction of a launch for the Christie School, West Coast Agency, I beg to say that the contract was let to Thomas and Hilmar Wingen, of Tofino, for the sum of $3,500.00, and it was arranged that payments should be made as the work progressed—the first when the hull was constructed ready for the installation of the engine; the second when the engine was purchased and properly installed; and the third on the completion of construction of the launch.

The hull is now ready for the engine and I am, therefore, sending in voucher No. 3A for $1,156.66 in favour of Messrs. Thomas and Hilmar Wingen, of Tofino, being the first payment, for which please forward a cheque to this office and I will send it on to the contracting company.

I am enclosing copy of the tender and also copy of the specifications. I am unable to send you a blue print at present as I returned to Reverend Father Radder the set he sent to me in October last and asked that he should have two sets sent to this office, but so far he has not done so. I will, however, call his attention to this matter.

Yours respectfully,

EXTRACT from Report of H. H. Barry, Inspector of Indian Schools for B. C., regarding his inspection of the Christie Indian Residential School on September 2nd, 1931, and forwarded under cover of Commissioner Ditchburn's letter of September 25th, 1931.

Original on File 159-0-6.

MANUAL TRAINING:

There are two classes of six boys each. Manual training is taught on two afternoons per week. The room used is about 45 ft. by 12 ft. and contains seven single benches. Each boy has a set of tools and there is a set for the instructor. These thirteen sets are in good condition.

Such articles as chicken coops and tables are made. No special course seems to be followed. The instructor is Mr. J. J. Kendrick. Mr. Kendrick does not appear to have had any particular training or certificate in Manual training.
Dear Sir:

Some time ago I received a communication from Reverend Victor Essier, Principal of the Christie Indian Residential School, at Kakawin on the West Coast of Vancouver Island, asking me if it would be possible for the Department to let him have about two thousand feet of well-seasoned clear cedar 1" x 12" x 12' long for manual training purposes.

After ascertaining from the local mills that the price of clear cedar was $65.00 per M. f.o.b. Victoria, I wrote the Reverend Principal asking him what this material was to be used for and his reply was to the effect that it was for the purpose of constructing lockers for the children and that the work would prove instructive to the boys in their manual training class.

My reply, dated the 1st ultimo, was to the effect that while I considered the work of constructing the lockers would prove instructive to the children, it was thought the expense of the construction could not be charged against the Manual Training Vote as the lockers themselves must be considered as an improvement to the building and while I considered such lockers were necessary I would have to apply to you for permission before any purchase could be made. I further added that in view of the high cost of cedar and the difficulty of getting the amount he asked for, he was requested to let me know whether kiln-dried fir would not answer his purpose as this could be purchased at between $35.00 and $40.00 per M.

The Reverend Principal's latest reply was to the effect that he would be satisfied if we could supply him with two thousand feet of clear fir and I, therefore, beg to ask your authority to purchase this material and have it shipped up the West Coast.

The Sidney Lumber Company, Cameron Lumber Company and Lemon, Gonnason Company, quoted a price of $45.00 per M. f.o.b. Victoria. The latter will necessarily be higher if the material is shipped from the Sidney Lumber Company as it would have to be handled a distance of twenty miles from Sidney to Victoria before being put aboard the West Coast boat. I am of the opinion that Lemon, Gonnason Company would be the best firm to purchase from in view of the fact that the Cameron Lumber Company is owned by American citizens though residents of Victoria.

Yours respectfully,

W. E. Ditchburn,
Indian Commissioner for B. C.
